This is a '''history of women in the United States'''.
==1500–1600== [[File:Virginia dare stamp.JPG|thumb|left|125px|A stamp honoring [[Virginia Dare]], who in 1587 became the first English child born in the United States.]]
The first European settlement inside what is now United States territory was founded in 1526. In that year a judge from [[Santo Domingo]], [[Lucas Vázquez de Ayllón]], obtained from [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles I, King of Spain]], a patent authorizing him to make settlements on the mainland of America, and to Christianize the American natives.<ref name=CatholicVirginia>{{cite web|url=http://www.newrivernotes.com/va/catholicva.htm|title=The Catholic Church in Virginia|year=1929}}</ref> Accordingly, with 600 settlers, including women, men, and children, he sailed to America from Puerto de la Plata, San Domingo, with three small vessels.<ref name=CatholicVirginia/> The settlers founded the colony of [[San Miguel de Gualdape]] at what is present-day [[Georgetown, South Carolina]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Myrtle Beach Retirement and Real Estate |url=http://www.retirenearmyrtlebeach.com/component/content/article/34-brunswick-county-nc/46-history-of-brunswick-county-nc.html |title=History of Brunswick County NC |publisher=Retirenearmyrtlebeach.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> This was the first European settlement in [[North America]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timepage.org/spl/13colony.html |title=13 Originals |publisher=Timepage.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> It also contained the first slaves brought to America, about 100 African people, who eventually staged a rebellion and fled into the forest, where they may have taken refuge with the Native Americans.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=wzWG2knfzb0C&pg=PA23 |last=Sharp |first=Pearl S. |last2=Schomp |first2=Virginia |title=The Slave Trade and the Middle Passage |page=23|isbn=978-0-7614-2176-4|date=September 30, 2006}}</ref> In any case, owing to the severity of winter, the hostility of the Native Americans, and internal discord, in the spring of 1527 all the settlers, under the leadership of Francis Gomez, reembarked for Santo Domingo in two of the vessels, one of which sank along with all on board, leaving only 150 of the people alive to reach their destination.<ref name=CatholicVirginia/>
[[Fort Caroline]], the first French colony in the present-day United States, was founded in 1564 in what is today Jacksonville, Florida.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mybaseguide.com/navy/kings-bay/communities.aspx |title=Military | Kings Bay Nsb | Community |publisher=MyBaseGuide.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref name=FortCaroline>{{cite web|author=Dale Cox |url=http://www.exploresouthernhistory.com/fortcaroline.html |title=Fort Caroline National Memorial - Jacksonville, Florida |publisher=Exploresouthernhistory.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> About 300 people founded this colony, including four women, 110 sailors, 120 soldiers, some artisans, and some servants.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=NclDpB3Fn5AC&pg=PA120 |title=Florida Almanac 2007-2008 - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=March 31, 2007 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=UcY20I7XXMAC&pg=PA18 |title=Four Centuries of Southern Indians - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> However, in 1565 the Spanish destroyed the French colony and built their own settlement in nearby St. Augustine, which became the first permanent European settlement in the continental United States. French leader [[Jean Ribault]] had left Fort Caroline virtually undefended, as he sailed in a growing hurricane to challenge the new Spanish presence in St. Augustine.<ref>{{cite web|author=Matt Soergel |url=http://jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/082408/lif_321895270.shtml |title=Fort Caroline: History buried in mystery |publisher=Jacksonville.com |date=August 24, 2008 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> The French at Fort Caroline had no idea that the Spanish were in the vicinity and were not prepared for this attack.<ref name=FortCaroline/> The Spanish soldiers stormed through the unlocked gates of the fort early on the morning of September 20, 1565, easily capturing the fort and many of its defenders.<ref name=FortCaroline/> It is believed that 40 or 50 of the French men escaped by leaping over the walls or taking refuge on boats in the river. All the French women and children who did not escape (there were about 50) were taken captive, and later shipped to Puerto Rico.<ref name=FortCaroline/><ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=Oh39ELdHh2wC&printsec=frontcover&dq=kenneth+hidden+history&hl=en&ei=Rr3GTY-wD8TTgAfrmcDMBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22puerto%20rico%22&f=false |title=America's Hidden History: Untold ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=September 8, 2010 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> The 140 or so men in the fort were killed.<ref name=FortCaroline/> St. Augustine was established in 1565, with 800 people founding it, including less than one hundred women (the exact number is unknown), 500 soldiers, 200 sailors, and some married men, children, and officials; all were from Spain.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=KL4YAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA232 |title=The Catholic church in the United ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=April 11, 2008 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
The first English people to arrive in America were the members of the [[Roanoke Colony]]. This colony was established in what is now North Carolina in July 1587, with 17 women, 91 men, and 9 boys as the founding colonists.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=eyExLN1prkYC&pg=PA142&lpg=PA142&dq=%22nine+boys%22+roanoke+colony&source=bl&ots=aV_gQ6eLH2&sig=xC-qwRndwcclqWBuBo0CGywbbww&hl=en&ei=iqgYTbKyIcWBlAfrtrm4DA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&sqi=2&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=%22nine%20boys%22%20roanoke%20colony&f=false |title=Colonial America and the American ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=June 25, 2006 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref name="NC Two Worlds">{{cite web|url=http://www.learnnc.org/lp/editions/nchist-twoworlds/1638 |title=Fort Raleigh and the Lost Colony - North Carolina Digital History |publisher=Learnnc.org |date=February 22, 1999 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> On August 18, 1587, [[Virginia Dare]] was born; she was the first English child born in the United States.<ref name="NC Two Worlds"/> She was the daughter of [[Eleanor Dare|Eleanor]] and [[Ananias Dare]] of the Roanoke colony, who were parishioners of [[St Bride's Church|St Bride's]] and were married in the church, and also had Virginia baptized there.<ref name=VirginiaDare>{{cite web|url=http://timelines.com/1587/8/18/birth-of-virginia-dare-first-child-born-in-the-americas |title=Birth of Virginia Dare, First Child Born in the Americas |publisher=Timelines.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> A bust of Virginia now stands above the baptismal font in the church.<ref name=VirginiaDare/> It is not known what happened to the members of the Roanoke colony; however, it is likely that they were attacked by Native Americans, and those not killed were assimilated into the local tribes.<ref name="NC Two Worlds"/>
==1600–1700== [[File:Pocahontas.jpg|thumb|right|Matoaka, better known by her nickname [[Pocahontas]]]]
Matoaka (better known by her nickname "[[Pocahontas]]," meaning "little wanton" or possibly "the naughty one" or "spoiled child"), was born about 1600 to the Native American [[chief Powhatan]].<ref name=Powhatan>{{cite web|url=http://www.powhatan.org/pocc.html |title=The Pocahontas Myth - Powhatan Renape Nation - the real story, not Disney's Distortion |publisher=Powhatan.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Powhatan had numerous wives (each wife gave him a single child and then was sent back to her village to be supported by the paramount chief until she found another husband), and thus Matoaka had many half-brothers and half-sisters.<ref name=PowhatansVirginia>{{cite web|url=http://www.historyisfun.org/pocahontas-and-the-powhatans-of-virginia.htm |title=Pocahontas and the Powhatans of Virginia |publisher=Historyisfun.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Her mother’s name is unknown.<ref name=PowhatansVirginia/>
The legend that she saved [[John Smith (explorer)|John Smith]] from being clubbed to death by her father in 1607 has no evidence behind it.<ref name=Powhatan/> Smith told the story for the first time seventeen years after it supposedly happened, and Smith also claimed that he was saved from death by a woman on two other occasions.<ref name=Powhatan/> The rescue legend was part of a longer account used as justification to wage war on Powhatan's Nation.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} Early histories did establish that Matoaka befriended Smith and the [[Jamestown, Virginia|Jamestown]] colony. She often went to the settlement and played games with the boys there. When the colonists were starving, "every once in four or five days, Pocahontas with her attendants brought him (Smith) so much provision that saved many of their lives that else for all this had starved with hunger."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://docsouth.unc.edu/southlit/smith/smith.html|title=Smith, ''Generall Historie'', p. 49}}</ref> But as the colonists expanded their settlement further, the Virginia Indians felt their lands were threatened, and conflicts arose again.
Matoaka was taken prisoner by the colonists while she was on a social visit in 1612, when she was seventeen, and was held hostage at Jamestown for over a year, during which time she converted to Christianity and agreed to marry [[John Rolfe]]. This marriage occurred in April 1614, resulting in her being given the name Rebecca Rolfe.<ref name=Powhatan/> She never married John Smith.<ref name=Powhatan/> Little is known about her life while imprisoned, although colonist [[Ralph Hamor]] wrote that she received "extraordinary courteous usage." Linwood "Little Bear" Custalow, in a 2007 book, asserted that Pocahontas was raped during this time, citing oral tradition handed down over four centuries. However, according to historian [[Helen Rountree]], "Other historians have disputed that such oral tradition survived and instead argue that any mistreatment of Pocahontas would have gone against the interests of the English in their negotiations with Powhatan."<ref>Rountree, Helen C. (December 8, 2010). [http://encyclopediavirginia.org/Pocahontas_d_1617 "Pocahontas (d. 1617)"]. [http://encyclopediavirginia.org/ Encyclopedia Virginia]. Retrieved March 4, 2011.</ref>
Matoaka's marriage to John Rolfe was the first recorded [[interracial marriage]] in American history.<ref>[http://www.oah.org/pubs/magazine/family/cruz-berson.html]{{dead link|date=June 2011}}</ref> This marriage brought a peace between the English colonists and the [[Powhatan]]s, and in 1615 Matoaka gave birth to her first child, Thomas.<ref name=PocahontasMarries>{{cite web|url=http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/4/5 |title=Pocahontas marries John Rolfe — History.com This Day in History — 4/5/1614 |publisher=History.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Matoaka and John Rolfe sailed to England in 1616.<ref name=PocahontasMarries/> Matoaka proved popular with the English gentry, and she was presented at the court of [[King James I]].<ref name=PocahontasMarries/> In March 1617, Matoaka and John prepared to sail back to Virginia.<ref name=PocahontasMarries/> However, the day before they were to leave, Matoaka died, probably of smallpox, and was buried at the parish church of St. George in Gravesend, England.<ref name=PocahontasMarries/>
Jamestown, the first English settlement in America, was established in 1607 in what is now Virginia.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN1127896220070513 | work=Reuters | title=FACTBOX-Jamestown, first English settlement in America | date=May 13, 2007}}</ref> The first women to arrive in Jamestown, Mrs. [[Anne Forrest]] and her fourteen-year-old maid, [[Anne Burras]], arrived in late 1608.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=555CzPsGLDMC&pg=PA152&lpg=PA152 |title=Jamestown Colony: a political ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In December 1608 Anne Burras married a carpenter and laborer named [[John Laydon]] in the first wedding ceremony held in Jamestown, and in 1609 they had a child named [[Virginia Laydon]] (not to be confused with Virginia Dare), who was the first child born in Jamestown.<ref name="bare_url">{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=orDbMGpInaQC&pg=PA457 |title=Virginia immigrants and adventurers ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=July 15, 2007 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref name="bare_url" /><ref name="Mary Quarterly">{{cite web|url=http://files.usgwarchives.net/va/schools/wmmary/quarterly/v15n1/pg39-41.txt |title=Jamestown Colony: a political ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref name="Mary Quarterly" /> The first American slaves since those in Lucas Vasquez de Allyon's unsuccessful colony in 1526–1527 were brought to Jamestown in 1619.<ref name="books.google.com">{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ScXpRj6su8EC&pg=PA51 |title=Voices of a People's History of the ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> These slaves were from the Caribbean, and there were twenty of them, including three women.<ref name="books.google.com"/><ref name="nwhm">{{cite web|url=http://www.nwhm.org/online-exhibits/africanamerican/index.html |title=Claiming Their Citizenship: African American Women From 1624-2009 |publisher=Nwhm.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
Also in 1619, 90 young single women from England went to Jamestown to become wives of the men there, with the women being auctioned off for 150 pounds of tobacco each (to be paid to the shipping company), as that was the cost of each woman's travel to America.<ref name="warm ups">{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=nA2mx68jgTkC&pg=PA31 |title=Voices of a People's History of the ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Such women were called "[[tobacco brides]]". There were many such voyages of women to America for this purpose (the 1619 voyage being the first), with the women promised free passage and [[Dowry|trousseaus]] for their trouble.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=rg7-dOq4ZXQC&pg=PA7 |title=America's Women: Four Hundred Years ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
On November 21, 1620, the [[Mayflower]] arrived in America (specifically in what is today [[Provincetown, Massachusetts]]), bringing the [[Pilgrim (Plymouth Colony)|Pilgrims]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americandaily.org/document/061121%20The%20Mayflower%20Compact.htm |title=www.americandaily.org |publisher=www.americandaily.org |date=April 8, 2011 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> There were 102 people aboard – 18 married women traveling with their husbands, seven unmarried women traveling with their parents, three young unmarried women, one girl, and 73 men.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=gMAUAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA1-PA58 |title=The Mayflower descendant: a ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=January 31, 2008 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Three of the married women – [[Elizabeth Hopkins]], [[Susannah White]], and [[Mary Allerton]] – had been in their last [[Pregnancy|trimester]] of pregnancy when the Mayflower left.<ref name=Mayflower>{{cite web|url=http://www.mayflowerhistory.com/History/women.php |title=MayflowerHistory.com |publisher=MayflowerHistory.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
No women died during the Mayflower's voyage; however, 78% of the women died during their first winter in America, a far higher percentage than for men or children.<ref name=Mayflower/> [[Dorothy Bradford]] was the first woman to die, and the only woman who died in the month of December; while many of the men, including her husband, were out exploring on [[Cape Cod]], she accidentally fell off the Mayflower into the waters of Provincetown Harbor.<ref name=Mayflower/> Only a few of the women's death dates were recorded: [[Rose Standish]] died on January 29, Mary Allerton died on February 25, and [[Elizabeth Winslow]] died on March 24.<ref name=Mayflower/> Most of the women died in February and March.<ref name=Mayflower/> The extremely high mortality rate among women is probably explainable by the fact the men were out in the fresh air, felling trees, building structures and drinking fresh New England water, while the women were confined to the damp and crowded quarters of the Mayflower, where disease would have spread much more quickly.<ref name=Mayflower/> The women continued to live on the Mayflower for four months after it docked, while the men built storehouses and living quarters onshore.<ref name=Mayflower/> Furthermore, many of the sick were probably cared for on board the ship by the women, increasing their exposure to colds and pneumonia.<ref name=Mayflower/>
Only five women survived their first winter in America, and one of the five survivors, [[Katherine Carver]], died in May, her husband John having died of sunstroke a month earlier.<ref name=Mayflower/> Therefore, by the time of the first Thanksgiving in autumn 1621, there were only four women from the Mayflower left alive: [[Eleanor Billington]], Elizabeth Hopkins, [[Mary Brewster]], and [[Susanna Winslow]].<ref name=Mayflower/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2002/1127/p13s02-lign.html |title=The first Thanksgiving / The Christian Science Monitor |publisher=CSMonitor.com |date=November 27, 2002 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Susanna Winslow was the widow of William White, who had died the first winter; she remarried to [[Edward Winslow]], whose wife Elizabeth had also died the first winter.<ref name=Mayflower/> Meanwhile, all of the wives who had been left behind in England were still living.<ref name=Mayflower/> Four of them came on the ship Anne in 1623, had additional children, and raised their families at Plymouth.<ref name=Mayflower/>
In the 1630s [[Anne Hutchinson]] began to hold religious meetings in her home, which attracted the attendance not only of women but of prominent men, including affluent young civil officials.<ref name="nwhm.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.nwhm.org/education-resources/biography/biographies/anne-marbury-hutchinson/ |title=Education & Resources - National Women's History Museum |publisher=NWHM |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Hutchinson’s charisma indeed was so great that it became a threat to the ability of the clergy to govern; this was especially clear when some of her male supporters refused to join the militia in pursuit of Pequot natives.<ref name="nwhm.org"/> The authorities, led by Reverend [[John Winthrop]] (who was also the colony’s governor), first attacked her indirectly by banishing her brother-in-law, a minister who shared her views.<ref name="nwhm.org"/> Hutchinson herself was summoned to trial late in 1637 and also banished, but allowed to remain under house arrest until the end of winter.<ref name="nwhm.org"/> In March, 1638, she was again brought before the court and formally excommunicated; she and her children soon joined her husband, who had prepared a home for them in the new colony of Rhode Island, which had been founded less than two years earlier by other dissidents exiled from Massachusetts.<ref name="nwhm.org"/> At nearly 47, Anne Hutchinson was once again pregnant and so severely ill that her physical condition had interfered with her ability to defend herself on trial.<ref name="nwhm.org"/> Her medical problem probably was a gross tumor of the placenta that had killed the fetus she delivered in late summer, but Puritan leadership — who saw all events in theological terms — deemed this “monstrous birth” to have been the judgment of God.<ref name="nwhm.org"/> In 1642, at age 51, she took her six children to the Dutch colony that now is New York; however, a year later, disgruntled Algonquians attacked her home, killing everyone but her youngest daughter Susanna, who was taken captive.<ref name="nwhm.org"/><ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=oAWfCh1PS8MC&pg=PA30 |title=Homework Helpers U.s. History: 1492 ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=October 17, 2006 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Today a river and a highway in that area bear the Hutchinson name.<ref name="nwhm.org"/> In 1660 [[Mary Dyer]], a [[Quaker]] who had been among Hutchinson's followers, was hanged in Massachusetts for her religious beliefs.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=hCRJO6gQL1|title=cc&pg=PA6}}</ref> The hangman, Edward Wanton, was so impressed by her he quit his job and became a Quaker himself.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=hCRJO6gQL1|title=cc&pg=PA13}}</ref>
There were two notable firsts for American women in the 1600s. In 1648 [[Margaret Brent]], an English immigrant to the Colony of Maryland, was the first woman in the English North American colonies to appear before a court of the Common Law. Appointed as [[Cecilius Calvert, 2nd Baron Baltimore|Lord Baltimore]]'s representative, on January 21, 1648, Brent attended the Provincial Court's assembly to request a voice in the council; she also asked for two votes in its proceedings (one as an independent landowner and the other as Lord Baltimore's attorney.) Governor Thomas Greene refused her request, as the assembly at the time considered such privileges for women to be reserved for queens. Brent left but said that she "Protested against all proceedings ... unless she may be present and have vote as aforesaid." In 1650 [[Anne Bradstreet|Anne Dudley Bradstreet]] became America's first published poet, with the publication of her book of poetry entitled ''The Tenth Muse Lately Sprung up in America''.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=-3GPn5EmQPkC&pg=PT1 |title=To My Husband and Other Poems - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=December 21, 2000 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> It was also published in London that same year, making Bradstreet the first female poet ever published in both England and the New World.
In 1655 [[Elizabeth Key Grinstead]], who was a slave in Virginia, won her freedom in a lawsuit based on her father's status as a free Englishman (her mother was a slave and her father was her mother's owner), helped by the fact that her father had baptized her as Christian in the Church of England.<ref name="google1">{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=UYWs-GQDiOkC&pg=PA223 |title=Women in early America: struggle ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> However, in 1662 the Virginia House of Burgesses passed a law stating that any child born in the colony would follow the status of its mother, slave or free.<ref name="google1"/> This was an overturn of a longheld principle of English Common Law, whereby a child's status followed that of the father; it enabled white men who raped slave women to hide the mixed-race children born as a result and removed their responsibility to acknowledge, support, or emancipate those children.<ref name="google1"/>
In the small Puritan community of [[Salem Village]], Massachusetts, the [[Salem witch trials]] began in 1692.<ref name="kids.nationalgeographic.com">{{cite web|author=Sara Zeglin |url=http://kids.nationalgeographic.com/kids/stories/history/salem-witch-trials/ |title=The Salem Witch Trials - National Geographic Kids |publisher=Kids.nationalgeographic.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> They began when a group of girls ([[Betty Parris]], her cousin [[Abigail Williams]], and several others) gathered in the evenings in the home of Reverend Parris to listen to stories told by one of his slaves, Tituba.<ref name="kids.nationalgeographic.com"/> They also played fortune-telling games, which were strictly forbidden by the Puritans.<ref name="kids.nationalgeographic.com"/> One night, while trying to see the faces of their future husbands in an egg white dropped in a glass of water, one girl believed she saw the shape of a coffin.<ref name="kids.nationalgeographic.com"/> Soon after, the girls began acting strangely, leading the Puritan community to suspect that the girls were victims of witchcraft.<ref name="kids.nationalgeographic.com"/>
The girls named three townswomen as witches - [[Tituba]], [[Sarah Good]], and [[Sarah Osborne|Sarah Osbourne]]; Tituba confessed to having seen the devil and also stated that there was a coven of witches in the Salem Village area.<ref name="kids.nationalgeographic.com"/> The other two women insisted they were innocent, but were found guilty of practicing witchcraft.<ref name="kids.nationalgeographic.com"/> As the weeks passed, the affected girls accused other townspeople of torturing them with witchcraft, and some on trial also named others as witches.<ref name="kids.nationalgeographic.com"/> By the end of the trials in 1693, 24 people had died, some in jail but 19 by hanging, and Giles Corey by being pressed to death.<ref name="kids.nationalgeographic.com"/> Some of the accused confessed to being witches, but none of those were hanged, only those who maintained their innocence;<ref name="kids.nationalgeographic.com"/> those who were hanged include 13 women and 6 men – Bridget Bishop, George Burroughs, Martha Carrier, Martha Corey, Mary Easty, Sarah Good, Elizabeth Howe, George Jacobs, Sr., Susannah Martin, Rebecca Nurse, Alice Parker, Mary Parker, John Proctor, Ann Pudeator, Wilmott Redd, Margaret Scott, Samuel Wardwell, Sarah Wildes, and John Willard.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.salemwitchmuseum.com/education/faq.shtml |title=Salem Witch Museum Education - Salem, Massachusetts |publisher=Salemwitchmuseum.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
==1700–1800== [[File:Abigail Adams.jpg|thumb|left|Abigail Adams.]]
The typical woman in colonial America (that is, America before the Revolutionary War) was expected to spin, sew, preserve food, cook, and clean while caring for her children and perhaps raising chickens and geese.<ref name="historyofquilts.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.historyofquilts.com/earlylife.html |title=New England Goodwives - Life for Colonial Women |publisher=Historyofquilts.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Families tended to be large, and childbearing was dangerous to health in those days; so many women died from that and other causes (such as the American climate's effect on their health) that the term "now-wife" was coined to refer to a man's present wife as compared to those that he had previously lost.<ref name="historyofquilts.com"/> Often women were taught to read so that they could read the Bible, but few learned to write as it was thought that there was no reason a woman should know how to write.<ref name="historyofquilts.com"/> Furthermore, a colonial woman was expected to be subservient to her father until she married and then to her husband.<ref name="historyofquilts.com"/> Ministers often told their congregations that women were inferior to men and more inclined to sin and error.<ref name="historyofquilts.com"/> However, several colonial American women had notable accomplishments that are known to this day.
The earliest known work of literature by an African American and by a slave, [[Lucy Terry]]'s poem "Bars Fight," was composed in 1746 and was first published in 1855 in Josiah Holland's "History of Western Massachusetts<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alamo.edu/sac/english/bailey/lterry.htm |title=Lucy Terry's " Bars Fight. " Text from San Antonio College LitWeb |publisher=Alamo.edu |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> ". The poem describes a violent incident that occurred between settlers and Native Americans in Deerfield, Massachusetts in 1746.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gibbsmagazine.com/Lucy%201.htm |title=Lucy Terry, the Slave History Singer |publisher=Gibbsmagazine.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Former slave [[Phillis Wheatley]] became a literary sensation in 1770 after she wrote a poem on the death of the evangelical preacher George Whitefield.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sonofthesouth.net/ |title=The Civil War |publisher=Sonofthesouth.net |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1773, 39 of Phillis Wheatley's poems were published in London as a book entitled ''Poems on Various Subjects, Religious and Moral''.<ref name="earlyamerica.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.earlyamerica.com/review/winter96/wheatley.html |title=Phillis Wheatley - America's First Black Woman Poet |publisher=Earlyamerica.com |date=February 27, 2007 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> This was the first published book by an African American.<ref name="earlyamerica.com"/>
In 1756 [[Lydia Taft|Lydia Chapin Taft]] became the first woman in American history to vote, casting a vote in the local town hall meeting in place of her deceased husband.<ref name="blackstonedaily.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.blackstonedaily.com/Journeys/cm-lt.htm |title=Blackstone Valley |publisher=Blackstonedaily.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref name="iwdc.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.iwdc.org/resources/timeline.htm |title=Blackstone Valley |publisher=Blackstonedaily.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated3>{{cite web|url=http://www.iwdc.org/resources/timeline.htm |title=Women in Politics: A Timeline |publisher=International Women's Democracy Center |work=Iwdc.org |accessdate=January 3, 2012 }}</ref> She voted that her town of [[Uxbridge, Massachusetts|Uxbridge]] (in Massachusetts colony) should increase the amount of money sent to help fight the French and Indian war.<ref name="blackstonedaily.com"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.merchantcircle.com/directory/MA-Uxbridge |title=Uxbridge coupons for pizza, grocery shopping, restaurants and more |publisher=Merchantcircle.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> She later voted in two other town hall meetings.<ref name="iwdc.org"/> Women had the right to vote in some states in early American history, but soon lost it. In 1777 women lost the right to vote in New York, in 1780 women lost the right to vote in Massachusetts, and in 1784 women lost the right to vote in New Hampshire.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite web|url=http://www.thelizlibrary.org/suffrage/ |title=The Liz Library Presents: The Woman Suffrage Timeline |publisher=Thelizlibrary.org |date=August 26, 1920 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Furthermore, women in all states except New Jersey lost the right to vote in 1787 when the Constitutional Convention placed voting qualifications in the hands of the states.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> From 1775 until 1807, the state constitution in New Jersey permitted all persons worth over fifty pounds to vote; free black people and single women therefore had the vote until 1807, but not married women, who could have no independent claim to ownership of fifty pounds (anything they owned or earned belonged to their husbands by law).<ref>[http://www.oah.org/pubs/magazine/earlyrepublic/cohen.html]{{dead link|date=June 2011}}</ref>
[[Deborah Sampson]] was the only woman who fought in the [[Revolutionary War]] (1775–1783).<ref name="search.barnesandnoble.com">{{cite web|url=http://search.barnesandnoble.com/Americas-First-Woman-Warrior/Lucy-C-Freeman/e/9781557785145 |title=BARNES & NOBLE | America's First Woman Warrior by Lucy C. Freeman | Hardcover |publisher=Search.barnesandnoble.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Women were not allowed to join the army, but in 1782 Deborah disguised herself as a man and joined the 4th Massachusetts Regiment, going by the name of Robert Shurtliff of [[Uxbridge, Massachusetts|Uxbridge]] and soon saw action in the front lines against the British.<ref name="search.barnesandnoble.com"/> When shot in the thigh she removed the musket ball herself, fearful of having her identity discovered.<ref name="search.barnesandnoble.com"/> However, her leg never healed properly, and her gender was finally revealed when she was hospitalized for a wound-related infection in 1783.<ref name="google2">{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=xFEC5tqvXsUC&pg=PA177 |title=The complete idiot's guide to women ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> But despite her deception, she was given an honorable discharge in recognition of her fine service.<ref name="google2"/> Furthermore, in the American Revolution women served on the battlefield as nurses and under many other jobs.<ref name="womensmemorial.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.womensmemorial.org/Education/timeline.html |title=Women In Military Service For America Memorial |publisher=Womensmemorial.org |date=July 27, 1950 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1776 at the battle of Fort Washington, Margaret Corbin fired her husband's cannon after he was killed, and was herself severely wounded in the battle, later receiving a pension from Congress in recognition of her service, making her the first American woman ever to receive a government pension.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=wg2ZO1SsQhgC&pg=PA174 |title=Great Graves of Upstate New York ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Also, in 1778 at the battle of Monmouth, Mary Ludwig Hays McCauley fired her husband's cannon after he was wounded in battle.<ref name="google3">{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=h-6WCBQPZdoC&pg=PA31 |title=Past and promise: lives of New ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Mary's deed, although a true story, is the source of the "Molly Pitcher" legend.<ref name="google3"/>
During the Revolutionary War in March 1776, [[Abigail Adams]] wrote to her husband [[John Adams]], who was one of the revisers and signers of the Declaration of Independence,<ref name="eyewitnesstohistory.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.eyewitnesstohistory.com/jefferson.htm |title=Writing the Declaration of Independence, 1776 |publisher=Eyewitnesstohistory.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref name="ushistory.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.ushistory.org/declaration/document/ |title=The Declaration of Independence |publisher=Ushistory.org |date=July 4, 1995 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> stating, "And, by the way, in the new code of laws which I suppose it will be necessary for you to make, I desire you would remember the ladies and be more generous and favorable to them than your ancestors. Do not put such unlimited power into the hands of the husbands."<ref name="thelizlibrary.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.thelizlibrary.org/suffrage/abigail.htm |title=Letters Of Abigail Adams |publisher=Thelizlibrary.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> However, John Adams replied in April 1776, "As to your extraordinary code of laws, I cannot but laugh...Depend upon it, we know better than to repeal our masculine systems."<ref name="thelizlibrary.org"/> Whether John Adams said this in irony, expressing frustration with his male colleagues, or in sincerity is unknown. The Declaration of Independence (written beginning in June 1776<ref name="eyewitnesstohistory.com"/>) and directed at the British monarch [[George III of the United Kingdom|George III]], who was asserting sovereignty through the [[Divine right of kings]] stated "All men are created equal" and did not mention women's rights.<ref name="ushistory.org"/> The Constitution, however, which was drafted after the King's claim of sovereignty was defeated in the [[Revolutionary War]], during a pre-government period of more than a decade, which was adopted by a [[Ratification of the United States Constitution|Ratification]] process, and which is the is the governing document in the United States, does not mention the term "Man" but refers to "Persons" or "People".<ref>{{cite book|last=Morgan|first=Edmund S.|title=Inventing the People: The Rise of Popular Sovereignty in England and America|year=1989|publisher=W. W. Norton & Company|isbn=0393306232}}</ref>
[[Rosemarie Zagarri]] (2007) argues the Revolution created an ongoing debate on the rights of woman and created an environment favorable to women’s participation in politics. She asserts that for a brief decade, a "comprehensive transformation in women’s rights, roles, and responsibilities seemed not only possible but perhaps inevitable" (p. 8) For example, the American Revolution produced the idea of "Republican Motherhood", which was the idea that if the republic of America were to succeed, women must be schooled in virtue so they could teach their children.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite web|author=ushistory.org |url=http://www.ushistory.org/us/12d.asp |title=Republican Motherhood |publisher=Ushistory.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Therefore, the first American academies for women were founded in the 1790s.<ref name="ReferenceC"/> However the opening of possibilities also engendered a backlash that actually set back the cause of women’s rights and led to a greater rigidity that marginalized women from political life.<ref>Rosemarie Zagarri, ''Revolutionary Backlash: Women and Politics in the Early American Republic'' (2007). 233 pp</ref> Furthermore, at least one story of women's participation in the American Revolution, the legend that [[Betsy Ross]] designed or made the first American flag, has no evidence at all behind it, although she was a real person who lived in Philadelphia during the Revolution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enjoyingphiladelphia.com/betsy_ross_frequently_asked_questions.html |title=Betsy Ross and the First U.S. Flag – Frequently Asked Questions |publisher=Enjoyingphiladelphia.com |date=December 19, 2010 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
There was also a significant portion of the population of the colonies and early United States, especially in the Delaware River Valley, who held cultural or religious views of sex equality. The [[Quakers|Quaker]] segment of the population held views that all human beings, regardless of sex, age, or race or other characteristics, had the same [[Inner light]].<ref>See, e.g.,{{cite book|last=Fischer|first=David Hackett|title=Albion's Seed: Four British Folkways in America|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-506905-1|pages=490–498|quote="On the subject of gender, the Quakers had a saying: "In souls, there is no sex." to g}}</ref> Quaker and Quaker-derived views informed the drafting and ratification of the Constitution, including through the direct influence of some of the [[Framers of the Constitution]], such as [[John Dickinson (politician)]] and [[Thomas Mifflin]], who were either Quakers themselves or came from regions founded or heavily populated with Quakers.
Two notable books published in the late 1700s by American women were ''American Cookery'' and ''[http://www.jsmsociety.com/Gleaner_LXXXVIII.html The Gleaner]''.''American Cookery'', written in 1796 by [[Amelia Simmons]], was the first known cookbook written by an American.<ref name="loc.gov">{{cite web|url=http://www.loc.gov/exhibits/treasures/tri054.html |title=A First American Cookbook (Imagination): American Treasures of the Library of Congress |publisher=Loc.gov |date=July 29, 2010 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> It was popular and was published in many editions, but only four copies of the original 1796 edition are known to have survived.<ref name="loc.gov"/> ''[http://www.jsmsociety.com/Gleaner_LXXXVIII.html The Gleaner]'', a three-volume book of political essays and plays published in 1798 by [[Judith Sargent Murray]], was the first self-published book by a woman in America. It became a minor classic, and was read by George Washington and John Adams.
==1800–1900== During the Lewis and Clark Expedition (1804–1806), which was the first overland expedition undertaken by Americans to the Pacific coast and back, the Shoshone woman [[Sacagawea]] was the only woman to accompany the 33 members of the permanent party to the Pacific Ocean and back.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/lewisandclark/inside/saca.html |title=Lewis and Clark . Inside the Corps . The Corps . Sacagawea |publisher=PBS |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> She joined the expedition in November 1804, after the explorers (Lewis and Clark) made winter camp at Fort Mandan in present-day North Dakota.<ref name="historynet.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.historynet.com/sacagawea-assisted-the-lewis-and-clark-expedition.htm |title=Sacagawea: Assisted the Lewis and Clark Expedition |publisher=History Net |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> The two captains hired her husband, the French-Canadian fur trapper Toussaint Charbonneau, as an interpreter, with the understanding that she would come along to interpret the Shoshone language, which she did. Sacagawea was only about 16 and was pregnant at the time.<ref name="historynet.com"/>
The Cult of Domesticity, a new ideal of womanhood was also created at this time.<ref name="library.csi.cuny.edu">{{cite web|url=http://www.library.csi.cuny.edu/dept/history/lavender/386/truewoman.html |title=True Womanhood |publisher=Library.csi.cuny.edu |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> This ideal rose from the reality that a 19th century middle-class family did not have to make what it needed in order to survive, as previous families had to, and therefore men could now work in jobs that produced goods or services while their wives and children stayed at home.<ref name="library.csi.cuny.edu"/> The ideal woman became one who stayed at home and taught children how to be proper citizens.<ref name="library.csi.cuny.edu"/> Nevertheless, many women of the time did work outside the home; for example, in the War of 1812 (1812–1815) Mary Marshall and Mary Allen worked as nurses aboard American commodore Stephen Decatur's ship ''United States''.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> Furthermore, during the War of 1812, in 1814 when the British army was advancing to the White House, First Lady Dolley Madison insisted on staying until the Gilbert Stuart painting of George Washington was rescued, and personally took the Declaration of Independence with her before leaving.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ot392Z890gIC&pg=PA50 |title=Failures of the Presidents: From the ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> With the help of volunteers and a wagon, she also took with her President Madison’s working papers from his desk, his books, some paintings, and the White House silver and china.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.firstladies.org/curriculum/educational-biography.aspx?biography=4 |title=Dolley Madison Juvenile/Educational Biography :: First Ladies' Library |publisher=Firstladies.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
Many women in the 19th century were involved in reform movements, particularly abolitionism.<ref>{{cite book|last=Jeffrey|first=Julie Roy|title=The great silent army of abolitionism: ordinary women in the antislavery movement|year=1998|publisher=UNC Press|isbn=0-8078-4741-0}}</ref> In 1831, Maria Stewart (who was African-American) began to write essays and make speeches against slavery, promoting educational and economic self-sufficiency for African Americans. The first woman of any color to speak on political issues in public, Stewart gave her last public speech in 1833 before retiring from public speaking to work in women's organizations.<ref name="pbs.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/aia/part4/4narr2.html |title=Africans in America/Part 4/Narrative:Abolitionism |publisher=Pbs.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Although her career was short, it set the stage for the African-American women speakers who followed; [[Frances Ellen Watkins Harper]], [[Sojourner Truth]], and [[Harriet Tubman]], among others.<ref name="pbs.org"/> Since more direct participation in the public arena was fraught with difficulties and danger, many women assisted the movement by boycotting slave-produced goods and organizing fairs and food sales to raise money for the cause.<ref name="pbs.org"/> To take one example of the danger, Pennsylvania Hall was the site in 1838 of the Anti-Slavery Convention of American Women, and as 3,000 white and black women gathered to hear prominent abolitionists such as Maria Weston Chapman, the speakers' voices were drowned out by the mob which had gathered outside.<ref name="pbs.org"/> When the women emerged, arms linked in solidarity, they were stoned and insulted.<ref name="pbs.org"/> The mob returned the following day and burned the hall, which had been inaugurated only three days earlier, to the ground.<ref name="pbs.org"/> Furthermore, the Grimke sisters from South Carolina (Angelina and Sarah Grimke), received much abuse and ridicule for their abolitionist activity, name="pbs.org"/> Furthermore, the Grimke sisters from South Carolina (Angelina and Sarah Grimke), received much abuse and ridicule for their abolitionist activity, which consisted of traveling throughout the North, lecturing about their first-hand experiences with slavery on their family plantation.<ref name="Pbs" /> Even so, many women's anti-slavery societies were active before the Civil War, the first one having been created in 1832 by free black women from Salem, Massachusetts<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=EzGVKN0BHFQC&pg=PR17&lpg=PR17 |title=We are your sisters: black women in ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Fiery abolitionist, [[Abby Kelley Foster]], was an ultra-abolitionist, who also led [[Lucy Stone]], and [[Susan B. Anthony]] into the anti-slavery movement.
Another important reform movement was the struggle of American women for education. In 1821, [[Emma Willard]] founded the Troy Female Seminary in Troy, New York, which was the first American educational institution to offer young women a college education equal to that given to young men.<ref name="jschell.myweb.uga.edu"/><ref name="jschell.myweb.uga.edu">{{cite web|url=http://jschell.myweb.uga.edu/history/women/troyfemale.htm |title=Troy Female Seminary |publisher=Jschell.myweb.uga.edu |date=October 16, 2001 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> The first three women in the United States to earn and receive their bachelor's degrees – Mary Hosford (later Fisher), Elizabeth Smith Prall (later Russell), and Mary Caroline Rudd (later Allen) – received them from [[Oberlin College]] in 1841;<ref name="oberlinheritage.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.oberlinheritage.org/researchlearn/historyfaqs |title=Oberlin History Frequently Asked Questions & Timeline |publisher=Oberlinheritage.org |date=June 17, 1933 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Oberlin College had become the first coeducational college in the United States in 1833.<ref name="oberlinheritage.org"/> Furthermore, Oberlin was also the first college to grant a degree to an African-American woman, Mary Jane Patterson, in 1862.<ref name="oberlinheritage.org"/>
[[File:Dix-Dorothea-LOC.jpg|thumb|left|[[Dorothea Dix]]]]
Another reform movement women were heavily involved with was the rights of those confined in institutions. [[Dorothea Dix]] was one of the most notable such reformers. Prior to the Civil War's beginning in 1861 (when she became the Union's Superintendent of Female Nurses), she investigated the conditions of many jails, mental hospitals, and almshouses, and presented her findings to state legislatures.<ref name="www25.uua.org">{{cite web|url=http://www25.uua.org/uuhs/duub/articles/dorotheadix.html |title=Dorothea Dix |publisher=5.uua.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Due to her work, many hospitals were built, along with additions and improvements made to existing facilities.<ref name="www25.uua.org"/> In contrast to popular attitudes of the time that such things were not necessary, she insisted on a therapeutic setting for the curable insane and a humanely comfortable setting for those regarded as incurable.<ref name="www25.uua.org"/>
During the Mexican War (1846–1848) Elizabeth Newcom enlisted in Company D of the Missouri Volunteer Infantry disguised as a man, calling herself Bill Newcom.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> She marched 600 miles from Missouri to winter camp at Pueblo, Colorado, before she was discovered to be a woman and discharged.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> Also, in 1846 Sarah Borginnis resupplied American soldiers with food while they were under fire, and was therefore nicknamed "the heroine of Fort Brown"; then-General Zachary Taylor rewarded her with the rank of brevet colonel.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=mjOcyvMwJ48C&pg=PA293 |title=Women's almanac 2002 - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
The first wave of feminism began with the [[Seneca Falls Convention]], the first women's rights convention, held at the Wesleyan Chapel in Seneca Falls, New York, on July 19 and 20, 1848.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=EoJrHDirVQUC&pg=PA12 |title=Encyclopedia of women and religion ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> This Convention was inspired by the fact that in 1840, when [[Elizabeth Cady Stanton]] met [[Lucretia Mott]] at the World Anti-Slavery Convention in London, the conference refused to seat Mott and other women delegates from America because of their gender.<ref name="npg.si.edu">{{cite web|url=http://www.npg.si.edu/col/seneca/senfalls1.htm |title=seneca falls |publisher=Npg.si.edu |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Stanton, the young bride of an antislavery agent, and Mott, a Quaker preacher and veteran of reform, talked then of calling a convention to address the condition of women.<ref name="npg.si.edu"/> An estimated three hundred women and men attended the Convention, including notables Lucretia Mott and Frederick Douglass.<ref name="npg.si.edu"/> At the conclusion, 68 women and 32 men signed the "Declaration of Sentiments and Resolutions", which was written by [[Elizabeth Cady Stanton]] and the M'Clintock family.<ref name="npg.si.edu"/> The style and format of the "Declaration of Sentiments and Resolutions" was that of the "Declaration of Independence"; for example the "Declaration of Sentiments and Resolutions" stated, "We hold these truths to be self evident, that all men and women are created equal and endowed by their creator with certain inalienable rights."<ref name="rochester.edu">{{cite web|url=http://www.rochester.edu/SBA/suffrage_sba_ecs.html |title=The Susan B. Anthony Center for Women's Leadership :: Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton |publisher=Rochester.edu |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> The Declaration further stated, "The history of mankind is a history of repeated injuries and usurpations on the part of man towards woman."<ref name="rochester.edu"/> It went on to specify female grievances in regard to the laws denying married women ownership of wages, money, and property (all of which they were required to turn over to their husbands; laws requiring this, in effect throughout America, were called coverture laws), women's lack of access to education and professional careers, and the lowly status accorded women in most churches.<ref name="rochester.edu"/> Furthermore, the Declaration declared that women should have the right to vote.<ref name="rochester.edu"/> Two weeks later a Woman's Rights Convention was held in Rochester, New York on August 2.<ref name="nps.gov">{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/wori/historyculture/womens-rights-movement.htm |title=Women's Rights National Historical Park - Women's Rights Movement (U.S. National Park Service) |publisher=Nps.gov |date=August 17, 2010 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> It was followed by state and local conventions in Ohio, Pennsylvania, and New York.<ref name="nps.gov"/> The first National Woman's Rights Convention was held in Worcester, Massachusetts in 1850.<ref name="nps.gov"/> Women's rights conventions were held regularly from 1850 until the start of the Civil War.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy98.org/move-hist.html |title=Legacy '98: A Short History of the Movement |publisher=Legacy98.org |date=September 19, 2001 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
In 1849 [[Elizabeth Blackwell]], born in England, graduated from Geneva Medical College in New York at the head of her class and thus became the first female doctor in America.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=PyoEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA22&lpg=PA22&dq=%22elizabeth+blackwell%22+%22valedictorian%22&source=bl&ots=LsN84RA2VG&sig=3j55Uo1oTa0roO3qov_Q4s-xk3Q&hl=en&ei=h8jATJKrEsSAlAfn7KSLCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22elizabeth%20blackwell%22%20%22valedictorian%22&f=false |title=The Crisis - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref name="socialstudiesforkids.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.socialstudiesforkids.com/articles/ushistory/elizabethblackwell.htm |title=Elizabeth Blackwell: America's First Female Doctor |publisher=Socialstudiesforkids.com |date=May 3, 1910 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1857 she and her sister Emily, and their colleague Marie Zakrzewska, founded the New York Infirmary for Women and Children, the first American hospital run by women and the first dedicated to serving women and children.<ref name="socialstudiesforkids.com"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nlm.nih.gov/changingthefaceofmedicine/physicians/biography_36.html |title=Changing the Face of Medicine | Dr. Emily Blackwell |publisher=Nlm.nih.gov |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> [[File:Harriet Tubman Civil War Woodcut.jpg|175px|thumb|right|Harriet Tubman.]]
Women continued to be active in reform movements in the second half of the 19th century. In 1851 former slave Sojourner Truth gave a famous speech, called "Ain't I a Woman?," at the Women's Convention in Akron, Ohio.<ref name="fordham.edu">{{cite web|url=http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/mod/sojtruth-woman.html |title=Modern History Sourcebook: Sojourner Truth: Ain't I a Woman |publisher=Fordham.edu |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In this speech she condemned the attitude that women were too weak to have equal rights with men, noting the hardships she herself had endured as a slave.<ref name="fordham.edu"/> In 1852 [[Harriet Beecher Stowe]] wrote the abolitionist book ''Uncle Tom's Cabin''.<ref name="digital.library.upenn.edu">{{cite web|url=http://digital.library.upenn.edu/women/stowe/StoweHB.html |title=Harriet Beecher Stowe |publisher=Digital.library.upenn.edu |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Begun as a serial for the Washington anti-slavery weekly, the "National Era", the book focused public interest on the issue of slavery, and was deeply controversial for its strong anti-slavery stance at the time it was written.<ref name="digital.library.upenn.edu"/> In writing the book, Stowe drew on her personal experience: she was familiar with slavery, the antislavery movement, and the underground railroad because Kentucky, across the Ohio River from Cincinnati, Ohio, where Stowe had lived, was a slave state.<ref name="digital.library.upenn.edu"/> ''Uncle Tom's Cabin'' was a best-seller, selling 10,000 copies in the United States in its first week; 300,000 in the first year; and in Great Britain, 1.5 million copies in one year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.harrietbeecherstowecenter.org/ |title=Welcome to the Harriet Beecher Stowe Center |publisher=Harrietbeecherstowecenter.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Following publication of the book, Harriet Beecher Stowe became a celebrity, speaking against slavery both in America and Europe.<ref name="digital.library.upenn.edu"/> She wrote ''A Key to Uncle Tom's Cabin'' in 1853, extensively documenting the realities on which the book was based, to refute critics who tried to argue that it was inauthentic; and published a second anti-slavery novel, ''Dred'', in 1856.<ref name="digital.library.upenn.edu"/> Later, when she visited President Lincoln, legend claims that he greeted her as "the little lady who made this big war," meaning the Civil War, but there is no proof this happened.<ref name="digital.library.upenn.edu"/> Campaigners for other social changes, such as Caroline Norton who campaigned for women's rights, respected and drew upon Stowe's work.<ref name="digital.library.upenn.edu"/>
In the years before the Civil War, [[Harriet Tubman]], a runaway slave herself, freed more than 70 slaves over the course of 13 secret rescue missions to the South.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newsone.com/nation/black-history-month/news-one-staff/the-liberator/ |title=The Liberator |publisher=News One |date=February 8, 2010 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Furthermore, in June 1863, Harriet Tubman became the first woman to plan and execute an armed expedition in United States history; acting as an advisory to Colonel James Montgomery and his 300 soldiers, Tubman led them in a raid in South Carolina from Port Royal to the interior, some twenty-five miles up the Combahee River, where they freed approximately 800 slaves.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.duboislc.net/read/Tubman'sCivilWarCampaign.html |title=Harriet Tubman’s Civil War Campaign |publisher=Duboislc.net |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
During the American Civil War (1861–1865) at least 240 biological women are known to have worn male clothing in order to serve; however, some of them, such as [[Albert Cashier]], were transgender men.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=deYLGaWeUCcC&pg=PA282 |title=They fought like demons: women ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Dorothea Dix served as the Union's Superintendent of Female Nurses throughout the war, placing her in charge of all female nurses working in army hospitals, which was over 3,000 nurses;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.civilwarhome.com/dixbio.htm |title=Dorothea Dix Biography |publisher=Civilwarhome.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> women provided casualty care and nursing to Union and Confederate troops at field hospitals and on the Union Hospital Ship ''Red Rover''.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> Furthermore, Dr. Mary Edwards Walker served as assistant surgeon with General Burnside's Union forces in 1862 and with an Ohio regiment in East Tennessee the following year; imprisoned in Richmond as a spy, she was eventually released and returned to serve as a hospital surgeon at a women’s prisoner-of-war hospital in Louisville, Kentucky.<ref name="army.mil">{{cite web|url=http://www.army.mil/women/early.html |title=Women in the U.S. Army |publisher=Army.mil |date=June 5, 1917 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> After the war, President Andrew Johnson awarded her the Medal of Honor, making her the only woman ever to receive it.<ref name="army.mil"/>
Also in 1866, Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Susan B. Anthony formed the [[American Equal Rights Association]], an organization for white and black women and men dedicated to the goal of suffrage for all.<ref name="memory.loc.gov">{{cite web|url=http://memory.loc.gov/ammem/naw/nawstime.html |title=Votes for Women: Timeline |publisher=Memory.loc.gov |date=August 26, 1920 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1868 the Fourteenth Amendment was passed, this was the first Amendment to ever specify the voting population as "male".<ref name="memory.loc.gov"/> In 1869 the women's rights movement split into two factions as a result of disagreements over the Fourteenth and soon-to-be-passed Fifteenth Amendments, with the two factions not reuniting until 1890.<ref name="memory.loc.gov"/> Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Susan B. Anthony formed the more radical, New York-based National Woman Suffrage Association (NWSA).<ref name="memory.loc.gov"/> [[Lucy Stone]], [[Henry Browne Blackwell|Henry Blackwell]], and [[Julia Ward How]]e organized the more conservative American Woman Suffrage Association (AWSA), which was centered in Boston.<ref name="memory.loc.gov"/> In 1870 the Fifteenth Amendment enfranchised black men.<ref name="memory.loc.gov"/> NWSA refused to work for its ratification, arguing, instead, that it be "scrapped" in favor of a Sixteenth Amendment providing universal suffrage.<ref name="memory.loc.gov"/> Frederick Douglass broke with Stanton and Anthony over NWSA's position.<ref name="memory.loc.gov"/>
From 1870 to 1875 several women, including [[Virginia Louisa Minor]], [[Victoria Woodhull]], and [[Myra Bradwell]], attempted to use the Fourteenth Amendment in the courts to secure the vote (Minor and Woodhull) or the right to practice law (Bradwell), but they were all unsuccessful.<ref name="memory.loc.gov"/> In 1872 Susan B. Anthony was arrested and brought to trial in Rochester, New York, for attempting to vote for Ulysses S. Grant in the presidential election; she was convicted and fined $100 and the costs of her prosecution but refused to pay.<ref name="memory.loc.gov"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Doug Linder |url=http://www.law.umkc.edu/faculty/projects/ftrials/anthony/timeline.html |title=The Susan B. Anthony Trial: A Chronology |publisher=Law.umkc.edu |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> At the same time, Sojourner Truth appeared at a polling booth in Battle Creek, Michigan, demanding a ballot; she was turned away.<ref name="memory.loc.gov"/> Also in 1872, Victoria Woodhull became the first woman to run for President, although she could not vote and only received a few votes, losing to Ulysses S. Grant.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.loc.gov/wiseguide/may06/women.html |title=The LOC.GOV Wise Guide : The First Woman to Run for President . . . 50 Years Ago? |publisher=Loc.gov |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> She was nominated to run by the Equal Rights Party, and advocated the [[Eight-hour day|8-hour work day]], graduated income tax, social welfare programs, and profit sharing, among other positions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://victoria-woodhull.com/whoisvw.htm |title=Who Is Victoria Woodhull? |publisher=Victoria-woodhull.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1874 The Woman's Christian Temperance Union (WCTU) was founded by Annie Wittenmyer to work for the prohibition of alcohol; with Frances Willard at its head (starting in 1876), the WCTU also became an important force in the fight for women's suffrage.<ref name="memory.loc.gov"/> In 1878 a woman suffrage amendment was first introduced in the United States Congress, but it did not pass.<ref name="memory.loc.gov"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.archives.gov/exhibits/featured_documents/amendment_19/ |title=Featured Document: The 19th Amendment |publisher=Archives.gov |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
American women achieved several firsts in the professions in the second half of the 1800s. In 1866 [[Lucy Hobbs Taylor]] became the first American woman to receive a dentistry degree.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nwhm.org/education-resources/biography/biographies/lucy-hobbs-taylor/ |title=Education & Resources - National Women's History Museum |publisher=NWHM |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1878 Mary L. Page became the first woman in America to earn a degree in architecture when she graduated from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=Jh7ecV24_uAC&pg=PA372 |title=Almanac of Architecture & Design 2006 - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1879 Belva Lockwood became the first woman allowed to argue before the Supreme Court; the first case in which she did so was the 1880 case "Kaiser v. Stickney".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.archives.gov/publications/prologue/2005/spring/belva-lockwood-1.html |title=Belva Lockwood |publisher=Archives.gov |date=November 11, 2010 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Arabella Mansfield had previously become America's first female lawyer when she was admitted to the bar in 1869.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.duhaime.org/LawMuseum/LawArticle-418/Mansfield-Belle-1846-1911.aspx |title=Mansfield, Belle (1846-1911) |publisher=Duhaime.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1891 Marie Owens, born in Canada, was hired in Chicago as America's first female police officer.<ref>{{cite web|author=   |url=http://abclocal.go.com/wls/story?section=news/local&id=7699254 |title=Historian: 1st woman joined CPD in 1891; Marie Owens joined as first female police officer in Chicago in 1891 as a detective sergeant | abc7chicago.com |publisher=Abclocal.go.com |date=September 30, 2010 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Due to women's greater involvement in law and law enforcement, in 1871 the first state laws specifically making wife beating illegal were passed, though proliferation of laws to all states and adequate enforcement of those laws lagged very far behind.<ref name="americanbar.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.americanbar.org/publications/human_rights_magazine_home/irr_hr_hr_summer02_fulcher.html |title=Domestic Violence and the Rights of Women in Japan and the US - Human Rights Magazine, Spring 1998 | Section of Individual Rights and Responsibilities |publisher=Americanbar.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
In 1889 [[Jane Addams]] and [[Ellen Gates Starr]] established the first settlement house in America (a settlement house is a center in an underprivileged area that provides community services), in what was then a dilapidated mansion in one of the poorest immigrant slums of Chicago on the corner of Halstead and Polk streets.<ref name="asteria.fivecolleges.edu">{{cite web|url=http://asteria.fivecolleges.edu/findaids/sophiasmith/mnsss141.html |title=Jane Addams Papers, 1904-1960 |publisher=Asteria.fivecolleges.edu |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> This settlement house, called Hull House, provided numerous activities and services including health and child care, clubs for both children and adults, an art gallery, kitchen, gymnasium, music school, theater, library, employment bureau, and a labor museum.<ref name="asteria.fivecolleges.edu"/> By 1910, 400 settlement houses had been established in America; the majority of settlement house workers were women.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=3K6APsAePzgC&pg=PA37 |title=The American century: a history of ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Jane Addams was also a noted peace activist who shared the Nobel Peace Prize with Nicholas Murray Butler in 1931<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ny77bPwKxaUC&pg=PA25 |title=The Nobel Peace Prize and the ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
In 1891 [[Queen Liliuokalani]], the last reigning monarch of the Hawaiian islands, ascended the throne.<ref name=liliuokalani/> The McKinley Tariff (passed in 1890) had begun to cause a recession in the islands by withdrawing the safeguards ensuring a mainland market for Hawaiian sugar, and American interests in Hawaii began to consider annexation for Hawaii to re-establish an economic competitive position for sugar.<ref name=liliuokalani>{{cite web|url=http://www.uic.edu/depts/owa/history/liliuokalani.html |title=Queen Liliuokalani |publisher=Uic.edu |date=November 11, 1917 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1893, Queen Liliuokalani sought to issue a new constitution through an edict from the throne, but could not as a group led by politician Sanford B. Dole overthrew her.<ref name=liliuokalani/> They had the help of the American minister in Hawaii, John L. Stevens, who called for troops to take control of Iolani Palace and various other governmental buildings.<ref name=liliuokalani/> In 1894 the Queen was deposed, the monarchy repealed, and a provisional government was established which later became the Republic of Hawaii<ref name=liliuokalani/> In 1895, Liliuokalani was arrested and forced to reside in Iolani Palace after a cache of weapons was found in the gardens of her home in Washington Place, although she denied knowing of the existence of this cache and was reportedly unaware of others' efforts to restore the royalty.<ref name=liliuokalani/> In 1896, she was released and returned to her home at Washington Place where she lived for the next two decades.<ref name=liliuokalani/> Hawaii was annexed to the United States through a joint resolution of the U. S. Congress in 1898.<ref name=liliuokalani/>
During the Spanish-American War (1898) thousands of US soldiers sick with typhoid, malaria, and yellow fever overwhelmed the capabilities of the Army Medical Department, so Dr. Anita Newcomb McGee suggested to the Army Surgeon General that the Daughters of the American Revolution (DAR) be appointed to select professionally qualified nurses to serve under contract to the US Army.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> Before the war ended, 1,500 civilian contract nurses were assigned to Army hospitals in the US, Hawaii (not a state at that time), Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam and the Philippines, as well as to the hospital ship ''Relief''.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> Twenty nurses died.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> The Army appointed Dr. McGee as Acting Assistant Surgeon General, making her the first woman ever to hold the position.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> The Army was impressed by the performance of its contract nurses and had Dr. McGee write legislation creating a permanent corps of Army nurses.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/>
==1900–2000== [[File:Martha Washington22 1903 Issue-8c.jpg|thumb|right|upright|The 1st Martha Washington postage stamp, issue of 1902.]]
There were various firsts achieved by American women in the early 1900s. In July 1900 [[Marion Jones]] won 3rd place in Women's Singles Tennis and 3rd in Mixed Doubles Tennis with her male partner from the United Kingdom at the second modern Summer Olympics in Paris, France. In October, Margaret Ives Abbott, Pauline Whittier, and Daria Pratt won the Women's 9 Hole Golf 1st, 2nd, and 3rd place, respectively. These were the only women's events (there were none at the first Olympics, and medals debuted later). In 1902, [[Martha Washington]] became the first woman to be honored on a U.S. postage stamp. In 1911 [[Harriet Quimby]] became the first American woman to earn a pilot's license.<ref name="harrietquimby.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.harrietquimby.org/pages/whowasharriet.html |title=Who was Harriet Quimby? |publisher=Harrietquimby.org |date=July 1, 1912 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In the spring of 1912, she became the first woman to fly a plane over the English channel;<ref name="harrietquimby.org"/> it was a 50 hp monoplane.<ref name="harrietquimby.org"/> In 1917 [[Jeannette Rankin]], a Republican from Montana, became the first woman elected to the House of Representatives.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-congress-women-20100829,0,6399682,print.story | work=Los Angeles Times | title=Latimes.Com | first=Lisa | last=Mascaro | date=August 29, 2010}}</ref>
[[Margaret Sanger]] was an influential campaigner for birth control rights in the 1910s. She originally worked as a visiting nurse in the New York City's tenements and wrote about sex education and women's health.<ref name="cdc.gov">{{cite web|url=http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm4847bx.htm |title=Margaret Sanger |publisher=Cdc.gov |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1914, Sanger's articles in "The Woman Radical" brought her a federal indictment for violating the [[Comstock laws|Comstock Act]] (which since 1873 had banned birth control devices and information on birth control devices, sexually transmitted diseases, human sexuality, and abortion<ref name="www-scf.usc.edu">{{cite web|url=http://www-scf.usc.edu/~nicoleg/history.htm |title=The Birth of The Pill |publisher=Scf.usc.edu |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>), prompting her to flee to England.<ref name="cdc.gov"/> As soon as the ship left U.S. waters, she cabled a radical publisher in New Jersey to tell them to distribute 100,000 copies of her birth control pamphlet, "Family Limitation".<ref name="cdc.gov"/> ". Sanger remained exiled in Europe until late 1915; William Sanger had been arrested and jailed for distributing one copy of "Family Limitation", and Margaret Sanger returned to face the charges against her.<ref name="cdc.gov"/> Personal tragedy intervened when the Sanger's five-year-old daughter died suddenly from pneumonia; public sentiments resulted in dismissal of the charges against Margaret Sanger.<ref name="cdc.gov"/> Rather than backing away from controversy, Sanger and her sister [[Ethel Byrne]], also a nurse, opened the first birth control clinic in the United States on October 16, 1916, modeled after those Sanger had seen in Holland.<ref name="cdc.gov"/> Nine days later police closed the clinic and arrested Sanger, Byrne, and the clinic's interpreter.<ref name="cdc.gov"/> Byrne was tried and convicted first, and went on a hunger strike; Sanger was convicted and served 30 days in jail.<ref name="cdc.gov"/> However, the publicity surrounding Sanger's activities had made [[Birth control movement in the United States|birth control a matter of public debate]].<ref name="cdc.gov"/>
The campaign for women's suffrage picked up speed in the 1910s. A parade for women's suffrage was held on Monday, March 3, 1913, down Pennsylvania Avenue in America's capital.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://memory.loc.gov/ammem/awhhtml/aw01e/aw01e.html |title=American Women: MARCHING FOR THE VOTE: REMEMBERING THE WOMAN SUFFRAGE PARADE OF 1913 |publisher=Memory.loc.gov |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Suffragist and lawyer [[Inez Milholland]] led the parade, clad in a white cape astride a white horse; behind her stretched a long line with nine bands, four mounted brigades, three heralds, about 24 floats, and more than 5,000 marchers.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> Furthermore, in 1916 Inez was the keynote speaker in a western pro-suffrage tour organized by Alice Paul.<ref name="laconneau.com">{{cite web|url=http://laconneau.com/womensaffairsInez1.html |title=Laconneau International - Spiritual Study and Meditation for Women |publisher=Laconneau.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Between one and two thousand people usually attended Inez’s speeches, which centered on the power of uniting women.<ref name="laconneau.com"/> Though she hid her pernicious anemia, the difficult traveling and speaking schedule made it worse, and she collapsed in October 1916 during her last public appearance.<ref name="laconneau.com"/> Inez was carried from the stage, but fifteen minutes later she returned, took a seat, finished her speech, and stayed for a question and answer session.<ref name="laconneau.com"/> That night she went into the hospital, and she died six weeks later.<ref name="laconneau.com"/> Inez’s last sentence before her collapse became a battle cry for suffragists: “Mr. President, how long must women go on fighting for liberty?”<ref name="laconneau.com"/>”
[[File:Suffragists picketing the White House.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Suffragists picketing in front of the White House.]]
In the spring of 1917, shortly after Woodrow Wilson had been inaugurated for his second term as President and war with Germany had been declared, women from the National Woman's Party (founded in 1913 by [[Alice Paul]] and [[Lucy Burns]]) began picketing the White House and the Capitol in support of an amendment that would guarantee women's suffrage.<ref name="memory.loc.gov"/><ref name="snopes.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.snopes.com/politics/ballot/womenvote.asp |title=Why Women Should Vote |publisher=snopes.com |date=September 6, 2008 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> By mid-June, [[Alice Paul]] had been warned by the chief of police that further demonstrations would lead to arrests, and between June 22 and 26, 27 women were arrested for obstructing traffic, but were released without penalty.<ref name="snopes.com"/> On June 26 several of the picketers were arrested and charged with obstructing traffic, and confined to the District Jail for three days after refusing to pay a 25 dollar fine.<ref name="snopes.com"/> The next series of arrests produced the same penalties; however, on July 14 sixteen women were arrested, tried, and sentenced to 60 days in Occoquan Workhouse in Virginia,<ref name="snopes.com"/> where the cells were infested with rats, and the food was infested with mealworms.<ref name="snopes.com"/> Furthermore, on November 14, 1917, newly convicted suffragists arrived at Occoquan and were waiting in a holding room; what happened to them has come to be known as the "Night of Terror".<ref name="snopes.com"/> Superintendent Whittaker burst into the room, followed by 15 to 20 guards (the exact number is uncertain) and shouted orders to take the suffragists to their cells.<ref name="snopes.com"/> May Nolan, a 73-year-old woman with a lame leg, was literally dragged off by two guards, despite saying that she would go willingly.<ref name="snopes.com"/> Dorothy Day had her arm twisted behind her back and was purposefully slammed down twice over the back of an iron bench.<ref name="snopes.com"/> Dora Lewis was thrown into a cell with such force that she was knocked unconscious, and for several minutes her companions believed that she was dead.<ref name="snopes.com"/> Alice M. Cosu of New Orleans was also thrown forcefully into her cell; she suffered a heart attack and repeated and persistent requests for medical attention for her went unanswered by the authorities throughout the night.<ref name="snopes.com"/> [[Lucy Burns]], who had been arrested once again on November 10, shortly after completing her previous 60-day sentence, was identified by Superintendent Whittaker as the ringleader for the group.<ref name="snopes.com"/> She was manacled to her cell bars, hands above her head, and remained that way until morning; later, her clothing was removed and she was left with only a blanket.<ref name="snopes.com"/> While in Occoquan, several suffragists went on hunger strikes and were subsequently placed in solitary confinement and subject to forced-feeding.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://memory.loc.gov/ammem/collections/suffrage/nwp/profiles.html |title=Photographs from the Records of the National Woman's Party - Profiles: Selected Leaders of the National Woman's Party - (American Memory from the Library of Congress) |publisher=Memory.loc.gov |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Crank |first=Glenda |url=http://www.womensenews.org/story/our-story/030718/suffragists-jailed-then-force-fed |title=Suffragists Jailed then Force-Fed |publisher=Womens eNews |date=July 18, 2003 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
