[[World War I]] (which America entered in 1917, and which ended November 11, 1918) was the first American war in which women were officially allowed to serve in the military (although some had served in previous wars by disguising themselves as men.<ref name="archives.gov">{{cite web|url=http://www.archives.gov/publications/prologue/2006/fall/yeoman-f.html |title=The Story of the Female Yeomen during the First World War |publisher=Archives.gov |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>) The Army Nurse Corps (all female until 1955<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.malenursemagazine.com/historyofmalenurses.html |title=Male Nurse Magazine |publisher=Male Nurse Magazine |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>) was founded in 1901, and the Navy Nurse Corps (all female until 1964<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.navalhistory.org/2010/05/12/happy-birthday-to-the-navy-nurse-corps/ |title=Happy Birthday to the Navy Nurse Corps | Naval History Blog |publisher=Navalhistory.org |date=May 12, 2010 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>) was founded in 1908, and nurses in both served overseas at military hospitals during the war.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> During the course of the war, 21,480 Army nurses served in military hospitals in the United States and overseas and eighteen African-American Army nurses served stateside caring for German prisoners of war (POWs) and African-American soldiers.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> More than 1,476 Navy nurses served in military hospitals stateside and overseas.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> More than 400 military nurses died in the line of duty during World War I; the vast majority of these women died from a highly contagious form of influenza known as the "Spanish Flu," which swept through crowded military camps and hospitals and ports of embarkation.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> In 1917 women were first able to join the Navy for jobs other than nurse; they were able to become yeomen, electricians (radio operators), and any other ratings necessary to the naval district operations.<ref name="archives.gov"/> 13,000 women enlisted, and the majority became yeomen and were designated as yeoman (F) for female yeoman.<ref name="archives.gov"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.warandgender.com/wgwomwwi.htm |title=The Women of World War I |publisher=Warandgender.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
Furthermore, in order to release men for the front lines, the Army employed 450 female telephone operators who served overseas, beginning in March 1918 and continuing until the war ended.<ref name="signal150.army.mil">{{cite web|url=http://signal150.army.mil/history-hello_girls.html |title=Signal Corps 150th Anniversary Commemorative Site - The Hello Girls |publisher=Signal150.army.mil |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> These women, who retained their civilian status and were not officially considered veterans until 1978, were the members of the Signal Corps Female Telephone Operators Unit 25, better known as the "Hello Girls".<ref name="signal150.army.mil"/> They were required to be fluent in both French and English,<ref name="signal150.army.mil"/> and assisted the French and British, both allies of America, in communicating with each other.<ref name="signal150.army.mil"/> On August 13, 1918, Opha Mae Johnson became the first female Marine when she enlisted in the Marine Corps Reserve; over 300 women served in the Marines during World War One, performing duties within the United States so that the male Marines could fight overseas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marines.com/main/index/winning_battles/history/leaders/pvt_opha_mae_johnson |title=Opha Mae Johnson - Marine Corps |publisher=Marines.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Also in 1918, twin sisters Genevieve and Lucille Baker became the first women to serve in the Coast Guard; they were the only women to serve in the Coast Guard during World War One.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.defense.gov/specials/womenhist2002/coast.html |title=Women's History Month Homepage |publisher=Defense.gov |date=November 23, 1942 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> After World War I ended in 1918, American women were no longer allowed to serve in the military, except as nurses, until [[World War II]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://userpages.aug.com/captbarb/femvets4.html |last=Wilson |first=Barbara A. |year=1996–2004 |title=WWI: Thirty Thousand Women Were There |accessdate=September 3, 2010}}</ref> However, in 1920 a provision of the Army Reorganization Act granted military nurses the status of officers with "relative rank" from second lieutenant to major (but not full rights and privileges).<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/>
The 19th amendment to the Constitution, giving all American women the right to vote, passed in 1920.<ref name="nytimes.com">{{cite news| url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/14/opinion/14collins.html | work=The New York Times | title=My Favorite August | first=Gail | last=Collins | date=August 13, 2010}}</ref> It came up before the House of Representatives in 1918 with the two-thirds votes needed for passage barely within reach; Representative Frederick Hicks of New York had been at the bedside of his dying wife but left at her urging to support the cause.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> He provided the final, crucial vote, and then returned home for her funeral.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> However, the Senate failed to pass the amendment that year.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> The amendment was approved by Congress next year on June 4, 1919, and the states started ratifying. In 1920, Tennessee was the 36th to do so, meeting the 3/4s (of then 48 states) required for enactment; the remaining states ratified later.<ref name="nytimes.com"/>
The amendment passed the Tennessee Senate easily.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> However, as it moved on to the House, vigorous opposition came from people in the liquor industry, who thought that if women got the vote, they would use it to pass Prohibition.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> Distillery lobbyists came to fight the amendment, bringing liquor.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> “Both suffrage and anti-suffrage men were reeling through the hall in an advanced state of intoxication,” suffragist Carrie Chapman Catt reported.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> Nevertheless, the suffragists thought they could count on a one-vote victory in the House.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> Then the speaker, whom they had counted on as a “yes” for the amendment, changed his mind.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> Yet suddenly, Harry Burn, the youngest member of the House, a 24-year-old "no" vote from East Tennessee, got up and announced that he had received a letter from his mother (Febb Ensminger Burn) telling him to "be a good boy and help Mrs. [Carrie Chapman] Catt."<ref name="nytimes.com"/> "I know that a mother’s advice is always the safest for a boy to follow", Burn said, switching sides, and the amendment was ratified that day, August 18, 1920, officially becoming part of the Constitution when it was signed into law on August 26, 1920.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> Suffragist Carrie Chapman Catt calculated that the campaign for women's right to vote had involved 56 referendum campaigns directed at male voters, plus 480 campaigns to get Legislatures to submit suffrage amendments to voters, 47 campaigns to get constitutional conventions to write woman suffrage into state constitutions; 277 campaigns to get State party conventions to include woman suffrage planks, 30 campaigns to get presidential party campaigns to include woman suffrage planks in party platforms and 19 campaigns with 19 successive Congresses.<ref name="nytimes.com"/>
The first wave of feminism is generally considered to have ended in 1920 when American women won the right to vote.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.servinghistory.com/topics/first-wave_feminism::sub::United_States |title=First-wave feminism : United States |publisher=Servinghistory.com |date=June 22, 2011 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> On August 31, 1920, five days after the 19th amendment was signed into law, Hannibal, Missouri, held a special election to fill the seat of an alderman who had resigned. At 7 a.m., despite pouring rain, Mrs. Marie Ruoff Byrum, wife of Morris Byrum and daughter-in-law of Democratic committeeman Lacy Byrum, cast her ballot in the first ward. She thus became the first woman to vote in the United States under the 19th amendment, as well as the first woman to vote in the state of Missouri.<ref>http://www.public.navy.mil/airfor/nalo/Pages/Women'sEqualityDay.aspx</ref>
[[File:Clara Bow Argentinean Magazine AD.jpg|thumb|right|125px|[[Clara Bow]], a famous actress and "It Girl" of the 1920s.]]
The "new woman" was in fashion throughout the twenties; this meant a woman who rejected the pieties (and often the politics) of the older generation, smoked and drank in public, had casual sex, and embraced consumer culture.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://historymatters.gmu.edu/d/5117/ |title=The New Woman of the 1920s: Debating Bobbed-Hair |publisher=Historymatters.gmu.edu |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Also called "flappers", these women wore short skirts (at first just to the ankles, eventually up to the knees) and bobbed hair in a short cut – like a boy's, but longer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.1920s-fashion-and-music.com/1920s-Flapper.html |title=1920s Flapper |publisher=1920s-fashion-and-music.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Just as the flapper rejected the long hair popular in earlier years, she also discarded Victorian fashions, especially the corset, which accentuated women's curves.<ref name="ehistory.osu.edu">{{cite web|url=http://ehistory.osu.edu/osu/mmh/clash/NewWoman/Subnarratives/the%20flapper.htm |title=The Flapper |publisher=Ehistory.osu.edu |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Flappers preferred to be slender, although it sometimes meant dieting or binding their breasts and wearing restrictive undergarments to appear thin, flat-chested, and long-limbed.<ref name="ehistory.osu.edu"/> Cultivating a flapper image and adhering to modern beauty standards also involved purchasing and applying cosmetics, which had not often been done previously by women other than prostitutes.<ref name="ehistory.osu.edu"/> These women further pushed the boundaries of what was considered proper for a woman by their public activities; swearing, smoking cigarettes, drinking alcohol (illegal from 1920 until 1933), dancing, and dating.<ref name="ehistory.osu.edu"/> The first appearance of the word "flapper" and the flapper image in the [[United States]] came from the popular 1920 [[Frances Marion]] movie, ''[[The Flapper]]'', starring [[Olive Thomas]].<ref name="olive">[http://www.assumption.edu/ahc/1920s/Olive%20Thomas/default.html ''Memories of Olive''.] assumption.edu.</ref> Thomas had starred in a similar role in 1917, though it was not until ''The Flapper'' that the term was used. In her final movies she was seen in the flapper image.<ref>Long, Bruce (editor). [http://www.public.asu.edu/~ialong/Taylor33.txt ''Taylorology: A Continuing Exploration of the Life and Death of William Desmond Taylor''.] Arizona State University.</ref> Other actresses, such as [[Clara Bow]], [[Louise Brooks]], [[Colleen Moore]], and [[Joan Crawford]] would soon build their careers on the same image, achieving great popularity.<ref name="olive"/>
Women achieved many groundbreaking firsts in the 1920s and 1930s. In 1921 [[Edith Wharton]] became the first woman to win the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction, due to her novel "The Age of Innocence".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.womenwriters.net/domesticgoddess/wharton1.htm |title=Edith Wharton |publisher=Womenwriters.net |date=July 14, 1998 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1922, [[Rebecca Felton]] of Georgia became the first woman appointed to the U.S. Senate; however, she served for only two days.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.distinguishedwomen.com/biographies/felton.html |title=Rebecca Ann Latimer Felton |publisher=Distinguishedwomen.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1923 the [[Equal Rights Amendment]], written by suffragist Alice Paul, was first introduced to Congress.<ref name="school.discoveryeducation.com">{{cite web|url=http://school.discoveryeducation.com/schooladventures/womenofthecentury/decadebydecade/1920s.html |title=Decade by Decade: 1920s - Women of the Century - DiscoverySchool.com |publisher=School.discoveryeducation.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Never ratified, the amendment states "Equality of rights under the law shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any state on account of sex.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.equalrightsamendment.org/overview.htm |title=Overview |publisher=Equalrightsamendment.org |date=June 30, 1982 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Also in 1923, [[Margaret Sanger]] opened the first birth control clinic in America, the Control Clinical Research Bureau in Manhattan, to provide contraceptive devices to women and collect accurate statistics to prove their safety and long-term effectiveness.<ref name="plannedparenthood.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.plannedparenthood.org/about-us/who-we-are/history-and-successes.htm |title=History & Successes |publisher=Plannedparenthood.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> That same year, Sanger incorporated the American Birth Control League, a new organization meant to work on the global issues of world population growth, disarmament, and world famine.<ref name="plannedparenthood.org"/> The two organizations subsequently merged, becoming [[Planned Parenthood]] Federation of America, Inc. (PPFA).<ref name="plannedparenthood.org"/> In 1925, [[Nellie Tayloe Ross]] became the first woman elected as a governor in the United States, for the state of Wyoming.<ref name="school.discoveryeducation.com"/> Also in 1925, the World Exposition of Women’s Progress (the first women’s world’s fair) opened in Chicago.<ref name="school.discoveryeducation.com"/> In 1926 [[Gertrude Ederle]], born in New York, became the first woman to swim across the English channel, arriving in almost two hours less time than any of the men who had swum across before her.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/donotmigrate/3672954/When-Gertrude-Ederle-turned-the-tide.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Gavin | last=Mortimer | title=When Gertrude Ederle turned the tide | date=April 27, 2008}}</ref> In 1928, women competed for the first time in Olympic field events.<ref name="school.discoveryeducation.com"/> Also in 1928, women earned 39% of all college degrees in America, up from 19% at the turn of the 20th century.<ref name="school.discoveryeducation.com"/>
In 1932 [[Hattie Caraway]] of Arkansas became the first woman elected to the Senate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=c000138 |title=CARAWAY, Hattie Wyatt - Biographical Information |publisher=Bioguide.congress.gov |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Furthermore, in 1932 [[Amelia Earhart]] became the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic, taking her journey on the 5th anniversary of Lindbergh's solo Atlantic flight .<ref name="ameliaearhart.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.ameliaearhart.com/about/achievements.html |title=The Official Website of Amelia Earhart |publisher=Ameliaearhart.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> She was awarded the National Geographic Society's gold medal from President Herbert Hoover, and Congress awarded her the Distinguished Flying Cross.<ref name="ameliaearhart.com"/> Later in 1932 she became the first woman to fly solo nonstop coast to coast, and set the women's nonstop transcontinental speed record, flying 2,447.8 miles in 19 hours 5 minutes.<ref name="ameliaearhart.com"/> In 1935 she became the first person to solo the 2,408-mile distance across the Pacific between Honolulu and Oakland, California; this was also the first flight where a civilian aircraft carried a two-way radio.<ref name="ameliaearhart.com"/> Later in 1935, she became the first person to fly solo from Los Angeles to Mexico City.<ref name="ameliaearhart.com"/> Still later in 1935, she became the first person to fly solo nonstop from Mexico City to Newark.<ref name="ameliaearhart.com"/> In 1937 Amelia Earhart began a flight around the world but vanished during it; her remains, effects, and plane have never been found.<ref name="ameliaearhart.com"/> The first woman to fly solo around the world and return home safely was the American amateur pilot [[Jerrie Mock]], who did so in 1964.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historynet.com/jerrie-mock-record-breaking-american-female-pilot.htm |title=Jerrie Mock: Record-Breaking American Female Pilot |publisher=History Net |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1933 [[Frances Perkins]] was appointed by President Franklin Roosevelt as his Secretary of Labor, making her the first woman to hold a job in a Presidential cabinet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spartacus.schoolnet.co.uk/USARperkins.htm |title=Frances Perkins |publisher=Spartacus.schoolnet.co.uk |date=May 14, 1965 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
However, women also faced many challenges during this time. A National Education Association survey showed that between 1930 and 1931, 63% of cities dismissed female teachers as soon as they became married, and 77% did not hire married women as teachers.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=https://netfiles.uiuc.edu/xtang2/www/w3.html#N_1_ |title=Women in World War II |publisher=Netfiles.uiuc.edu |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Also, a survey of 1,500 cities from 1930 to 1931 found that three-quarters of those cities did not employ married women for any jobs.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=PQzmjgSObrEC&pg=PA128&lpg=PA128 |title=Race, gender, and work: a multi ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In January 1932, Congress passed the Federal Economy Act which stipulated that no two persons in the family could be working in government service at the same time; three-fourths of employees discharged as a result of this Act were women.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> However, during the [[Great Depression]] white women's unemployment rate was actually lower than that for men, because women were paid less and because men would not take what they considered to be "women's jobs" such as clerical work or domestic service.<ref name="google4">{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=PQzmjgSObrEC&pg=PA128 |title=Race, gender, and work: a multi ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Yet as a result of rising unemployment, white women's movement into professional and technical work slowed.<ref name="google4"/>
Birth control activism was an important cause in the 1930s. In 1936 [[Margaret Sanger]] helped bring the case of "[[United States v. One Package of Japanese Pessaries|United States v. One Package]]" to the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals.<ref name="www-scf.usc.edu"/> The decision in that case allowed physicians to legally mail birth control devices and information; however, it applied only to New York, Connecticut, and Vermont; birth control did not become legal for married couples throughout the United States until the 1965 Supreme Court decision [[Griswold v. Connecticut]], and did not become legal for unmarried couples throughout the United States until the 1972 Supreme Court decision [[Eisenstadt v. Baird]].<ref name="www-scf.usc.edu"/><ref name="plannedparenthood.org"/><ref>{{cite web|author=linderd |url=http://www.law.umkc.edu/faculty/projects/ftrials/conlaw/griswold.html |title=Griswold vs Connecticut |publisher=Law.umkc.edu |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oyez.org/cases/1970-1979/1971/1971_70_17 |title=Eisenstadt v. Baird | The Oyez Project at IIT Chicago-Kent College of Law |publisher=Oyez.org |date=March 22, 1972 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1937 The American Medical Association officially recognized birth control as an integral part of medical practice and education, and North Carolina became the first state to recognize birth control as a public health measure and to provide contraceptive services to indigent mothers through its public health program.<ref name="plannedparenthood.org"/>
In 1939 black singer [[Marian Anderson]] sang on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial, which was considered a milestone in the civil rights movement.<ref name="pri.org">{{cite web|author=The Takeaway |url=http://www.pri.org/arts-entertainment/music/marian-anderson-lincoln-memorial.html |title=Singer Marian Anderson's Lincoln Memorial legacy |publisher=Pri.Org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> She had originally wanted to sing at Washington D.C.'s largest venue, Constitution Hall, but The Daughters of the American Revolution barred her from performing there because of her race.<ref name="pri.org"/> Due to this, Eleanor Roosevelt, who was then the First Lady, resigned from the organization.<ref name="pri.org"/> This stands as one of the first actions taken by someone in the White House to address the era's racial inequality.<ref name="pri.org"/> Anderson performed at the White House three years prior in 1936, making her the first African-American performer to do so.<ref name="pri.org"/>
[[File:Wendy Welder Richmond Shipyards.jpg|thumb|right|A female welder at the Richmond Shipyards, Richmond, California, in 1943. Women factory workers embodied the "[[Rosie the Riveter]]" ideal.]]
When the United States entered World War II in 1941, 12 million women were already working (making up one quarter of the workforce), and by the end of the war, the number was up to 18 million (one third of the workforce).<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/pwro/collection/website/rosie.htm |title=Rosie the Riveter: Women Working During World War II |publisher=Nps.gov |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> However, while eventually 3 million women worked in war plants, the majority of women who worked during World War II worked in traditionally female occupations, like the service sector.<ref name="autogenerated2"/> During this time, the "[[Rosie the Riveter]]" concept became popular with working women.<ref name="autogenerated2"/>
Furthermore, during World War II 350,000 women served in the military, as [[Women's Army Corps (United States Army)|WACS]], [[WAVES]], [[SPARS]], Marines and nurses.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> More than 60,000 Army nurses served stateside and overseas during World War II; 67 Army nurses were captured by the Japanese in the Philippines in 1942 and were held as POWs for over two and a half years.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> More than 14,000 Navy nurses served stateside, overseas on hospital ships, and as flight nurses during the war.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> Five Navy nurses were captured by the Japanese on the island of Guam and held as POWs for five months before being exchanged; a second group of eleven Navy nurses were captured by the Japanese in the Philippines and held for 37 months.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/>
Over 150,000 American women served in the Women's Army Corps (WAC) during World War II; the Corps was formed in 1942.<ref name="history.army.mil">{{cite web|url=http://www.history.army.mil/brochures/wac/wac.htm |title=The Women's Army Corps |publisher=History.army.mil |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Many Army WACs computed the velocity of bullets, measured bomb fragments, mixed gunpowder, and loaded shells.<ref name="history.army.mil"/> Others worked as draftswomen, mechanics, and electricians, and some received training in ordnance engineering.<ref name="history.army.mil"/> Later in the war, women were trained to replace men as radio operators on U.S. Army hospital ships.<ref name="history.army.mil"/> The "Larkspur", the "Charles A. Stafford", and the "Blanche F. Sigman" each received three enlisted women and one officer near the end of 1944.<ref name="history.army.mil"/> This experiment proved successful, and the assignment of female secretaries and clerical workers to hospital ships occurred soon after.<ref name="history.army.mil"/>
Eventually the Air Force obtained 40% of all WACs in the Army; women were assigned as weather observers and forecasters, cryptographers, radio operators and repairmen, sheet metal workers, parachute riggers, link trainer instructors, bombsight maintenance specialists, aerial photograph analysts, and control tower operators.<ref name="history.army.mil"/> Over 1,000 WACs ran the statistical control tabulating machines (the precursors of modern-day computers) used to keep track of personnel records.<ref name="history.army.mil"/> By January 1945 only 50% of AAF WACs held traditional assignments such as file clerk, typist, and stenographer.<ref name="history.army.mil"/> A few Air Force WACs were assigned flying duties; two WAC radio operators assigned to Mitchel Field, New York, flew as crew members on B-17 training flights.<ref name="history.army.mil"/> WAC mechanics and photographers also made regular flights.<ref name="history.army.mil"/> Three WACs were awarded Air Medals, including one in India for her work in mapping "the Hump," the mountainous air route overflown by pilots ferrying lend-lease supplies to the Chinese Army.<ref name="history.army.mil"/> One woman died in the crash of an aerial broadcasting plane.<ref name="history.army.mil"/>
In 1942 the WAVES (Women Accepted for Volunteer Emergency Service) division was founded as an all-female division of the Navy, and more than 80,000 women served in it, including computer scientist [[Grace Hopper]], who later achieved the rank of rear admiral.<ref name="newstimes.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.newstimes.com/local/article/Faces-of-Freedom-Danbury-woman-rode-WAVES-into-608710.php |title=Faces of Freedom: Danbury woman rode WAVES into the Navy |publisher=NewsTimes |date=August 9, 2010 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> While traditionally female secretarial and clerical jobs took a large portion of the WAVES women, thousands of WAVES performed previously atypical duties in the aviation community, Judge Advocate General Corps, medical professions, communications, intelligence, science and technology.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.history.navy.mil/photos/prs-tpic/females/wave-ww2.htm |title=Women & the U.S. Navy - WWII era WAVES |publisher=History.navy.mil |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> The WAVES ended and women were accepted into the regular Navy in 1948.<ref name="newstimes.com"/> The first six enlisted women to be sworn into the regular Navy on July 7, 1948 were Kay Langdon, Wilma Marchal, Edna Young, Frances Devaney, Doris Robertson. and Ruth Flora.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.history.navy.mil/wars/datesjul.htm |title=Dates in Naval History: July |publisher=History.navy.mil |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> On October 15, 1948, the first eight women to be commissioned in the regular Navy, Joy Bright Hancock, Winifred Quick Collins, Ann King, Frances Willoughby, Ellen Ford, Doris Cranmore, Doris Defenderfer, and Betty Rae Tennant took their oaths as naval officers.<ref>Ebbert, Jean; and Hall, Marie-Beth; ''Crossed Currents: Navy Women from WWI to Tailhook Revised'': Brassey's; 1999.</ref>
Semper Paratus Always Ready, better known as SPARS, was the United States Coast Guard Women’s Reserve, created Nov. 23, 1942; more than 11,000 women served in SPARS during World War II.<ref name="uscg.mil">{{cite web|url=http://www.uscg.mil/history/uscghist/WomenChronology.asp |title=Women's History Chronology |publisher=Uscg.mil |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> SPARs were assigned stateside and served as storekeepers, clerks, photographers, pharmacist's mates, cooks, and in numerous other jobs.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> The program was largely demobilized after the war.<ref name="uscg.mil"/>
The Marine Corps created a Women's Reserve in 1943; women served as Marines during the war in over 225 different specialties, filling 85% of the enlisted jobs at Headquarters Marine Corps and comprising one-half to two-thirds of the permanent personnel at major Marine Corps posts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.womensmemorial.org/H&C/History/wwii(mcwr).html |title=Women In Military Service For America Memorial |publisher=Womensmemorial.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Marine women served stateside as clerks, cooks, mechanics, drivers, and in a variety of other positions.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/>
The Women's Airforce Service Pilots (also known as [[Women Airforce Service Pilots|WASP]]) was created in 1943 to free male pilots for combat service. WASPs flew stateside missions as ferriers, test pilots, and anti-aircraft artillery trainers.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> Some 25,000 women applied to join the WASP, but only 1,830 were accepted and took the oath, and out of those only 1,074 women passed the training and joined.<ref name=Idaho/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.computer-history.info/Page1.dir/pages/Gee.html |title=An Interview with Margaret Gee |publisher=Computer-history.info |date=February 11, 1998 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> The WASPs flew over 60 million miles in all, in every type of military aircraft.<ref name=Idaho>[http://www.flyidaho.org/events.asp?order=past&menuID=15~15]{{dead link|date=June 2011}}</ref> WASPs were granted [[veteran]] status in 1977, and given the Congressional Gold Medal in 2009.<ref>[http://thune.senate.gov/public/index.cfm?FuseAction=PressReleases.Detail&PressRelease_id=026b5888-86e0-4688-a4fc-e9e680ea96e4&Month=5&Year=2009]{{dead link|date=June 2011}}</ref>
Many women were spies for America during World War II, for example the singer Josephine Baker, whose long residency in France helped her form an underground network, and Claire Phillips, a spy in the Philippines (then occupied by Japan) who in addition to spying sent aid and supplies to the American POWs; Claire was tortured, but never admitted to knowing the people in her spy ring, and after the war she was recognized by the American and Philippine governments for her heroism.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=wiDHD7UhJYYC&pg=PA68&lpg=PA68 |title=War stories two - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=November 25, 2004 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{ASIN | 9719360704 }}</ref><ref>{{ASIN | 0823944492 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=sDVUcuAUCUwC&pg=PA406 |title=1942: The Year That Tried Men's Souls - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
Once World War II ended in 1945, civilian female workers were expected to give up their jobs to returning male veterans and go back home to have and raise children put off by the war.<ref name="westga.edu">{{cite web|url=http://www.westga.edu/~hgoodson/Women%20and%20Work.htm |title=Women and Work |publisher=Westga.edu |date=September 15, 1952 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1946, 4 million women were fired from their jobs.<ref name="westga.edu"/> But for many women, work was an economic necessity, and they simply went back to the sort of [[low-paying job]]s they had held before the war.<ref name="westga.edu"/> However, most people in the 1950s felt that ideally women should be homemakers and men should be breadwinners.<ref name="93778645.nhd.weebly.com">{{cite web|url=http://93778645.nhd.weebly.com/the-1950s.html |title=The 1950s - The Pill: Birth of a New Woman |publisher=93778645.nhd.weebly.com |date=January 4, 1965 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> A booming economy helped to make this possible; by the mid-1950s, 40% of Americans were living in the suburbs with, on average, 3.8 children, two cars and two television sets.<ref name="93778645.nhd.weebly.com"/> Although 35% of women did go to college in the 1950s, most attended not to learn skills but to find a husband.<ref name="93778645.nhd.weebly.com"/> Furthermore, although 46% of women worked during the 1950s, 75% of them worked in simple clerical or sales jobs.<ref name="93778645.nhd.weebly.com"/> The average working woman in the 1950s earned 60% of the average working man's salary.<ref name="93778645.nhd.weebly.com"/>
However, there were still advances for women in the military. The Army-Navy Nurse Act of 1947 made the Army Nurse Corps and Women's Medical Specialist Corps part of the regular Army and gave permanent commissioned officer status to Army and Navy nurses.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> In 1948 Congress passed the Women's Armed Forces Integration Act, which authorized women to enlist in the military alongside men, rather than in their own separate units, although women were still not allowed to serve in combat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmcpress.com/heritage/women_marines.htm |title=Women Marines |publisher=Usmcpress.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.defense.gov/transcripts/transcript.aspx?transcriptid=1642 |title=News Transcript: 50th Anniversary of the Women's Armed Services Integration Act of 1948 |publisher=Defense.gov |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Furthermore, in 1948 Executive Order 9981 ended racial segregation in the armed services.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> In 1949 the Air Force Nurse Corps was established (the Air Force itself was created in 1947).<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> That same year, the first African-American women enlisted in the Marine Corps.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/>
The [[Korean War]] was fought from 1950 until 1953.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> Many servicewomen who had joined the Reserves following World War II were involuntarily recalled to active duty during the Korean War.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> 540 Army nurses (all military nurses during the Korean War were female) served in the combat zone and many more were assigned to large hospitals in Japan during the war.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/><ref name="archives1">{{cite web|url=http://www.archives.gov/research/korean-war/nurses.html |title=Please Update Your Bookmark |publisher=Archives.gov |date=October 19, 2011 |accessdate=April 3, 2012}}</ref> One Army nurse (Genevieve Smith) died in a plane crash en route to Korea on July 27, 1950, shortly after hostilities began.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/><ref name="archives1"/> Navy nurses served on hospital ships in the Korean theater of war as well as at Navy hospitals stateside.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> Eleven Navy nurses died en route to Korea when their plane crashed in the Marshall Islands.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> Air Force nurses served stateside, in Japan and as flight nurses in the Korean theater during the war.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> Three Air Force nurses were killed in plane crashes while on duty.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> Many other servicewomen were assigned to duty in the theater of operations in Japan and Okinawa.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/>
Women were heavily involved in lesbian rights and civil rights throughout the 1950s. In 1955 the first national lesbian political and social organization in the United States, called Daughters of Bilitis, was founded by four lesbian couples in San Francisco (including [[Del Martin and Phyllis Lyon]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.glbtq.com/social-sciences/daughters_bilitis.html |title=>> social sciences >> Daughters of Bilitis |publisher=glbtq |date=October 20, 2005 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> On December 1, 1955, [[Rosa Parks]], a seamstress and volunteer secretary for the NAACP, was arrested in Montgomery, Alabama for refusing to give up her seat on a bus to a white man, as required by law at the time; shortly after this a bus boycott began, inspired by her actions, advocating for an end to all segregated busing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hfmgv.org/exhibits/rosaparks/story.asp |title=Rosa Parks Bus - The Story Behind the Bus |publisher=Hfmgv.org |date=December 1, 1955 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ZRl0yhs2ESUC&pg=PA1897&dq=%22rosa+parks%22+%221955%22&hl=en&ei=vLuBTK3cIYK78gaEt5XKAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=book-thumbnail&resnum=2&ved=0CDQQ6wEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22rosa%20parks%22%20%221955%22&f=false |title=Rosa Parks: Freedom Rider - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=February 4, 1913 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> The night of Rosa Parks' arrest, with her permission, Mrs. [[Jo Ann Robinson]] stayed up mimeographing 35,000 handbills calling for a boycott of the Montgomery bus system. Prior to Rosa Parks' action, Claudette Colvin and Mary Louise Smith had refused to give up their seats on buses to white women, but their cases were rejected by civil rights lawyers as they were not considered sympathetic enough.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/26/books/26colvin.html | work=The New York Times | first=Brooks | last=Barnes | title=From Footnote to Fame in Civil Rights History | date=November 26, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=0jwWrG4V1XQC&pg=PA319&lpg=PA319&dq=%22mary+louise+smith%22%22white+woman%22&source=bl&ots=B6l6kQgyKl&sig=V1BfGqsuXGGhJxms_x9dZkALUko&hl=en&ei=27I7TYfBGsL3gAfT_6z0CA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22mary%20louise%20smith%22%22white%20woman%22&f=false |title=This Day in Civil Rights History - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref name="montgomeryboycott.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.montgomeryboycott.com/bio_colvin.htm |title=Montgomery Bus Boycott: The story of Rosa Parks and the Civil Rights Movement |publisher=Montgomeryboycott.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref name="montgomeryboycott.com"/> Aurelia Shines Browder refused to give up her seat to a white man in Montgomery, Alabama in April 1955, and she filed suit against the city and its Mayor W.A. "Tacky" Gayle.<ref name="montgomeryboycott">{{cite web|url=http://www.montgomeryboycott.com/profile_browder.htm |title=Montgomery Bus Boycott: The story of Rosa Parks and the Civil Rights Movement |publisher=Montgomeryboycott.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=QehPhNwc_FkC&pg=PA233&lpg=PA233&dq=aurelia+%22white+woman%22+bus&source=bl&ots=xZ56jkdkCj&sig=kncOKEczC9_JFIuTCDdk3gQULrU&hl=en&ei=VbM7TcqXJsnogAf1kuXJCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBMQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=aurelia%20%22white%20woman%22%20bus&f=false |title=Freedom by any means: con games ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=October 21, 1955 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> It was on her case, known as Browder v Gayle, that the Supreme Court ruled in 1956 that segregated busing was unconstitutional, thus ending the bus boycott.<ref name="montgomeryboycott" /> Aurelia Browder was the lead plaintiff in the case, and Susie McDonald, Claudette Colvin, and Mary Louise Smith were the other plaintiffs.<ref name="montgomeryboycott" /><ref>[http://www.tolerance.org/activity/browder-v-gayle-women-rosa-parks]{{dead link|date=June 2011}}</ref>
Yet women still occupied a lower position than men in many sectors of American life. In 1957, the National Manpower Council (NMC) at Columbia University published its study, "Womanpower, A Statement by the National Manpower Council with Chapters by the Council Staff".<ref name="feminist.org">{{cite web|url=http://feminist.org/research/chronicles/part1a.html |title=The Feminist Chronicles, 1953-1993 - Part I - "... a passion for the possible" - Feminist Majority Foundation |publisher=Feminist.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> It was a comprehensive look at the experience of women in the labor force, their employment needs, and the implications of both for education, training, and public policy.<ref name="feminist.org"/> This NMC analysis called women "essential" and "distinctive" workers and recommended that the Secretary of Labor establish a committee to review "the consequences and adequacy of existing Federal and state laws which have a direct bearing on the employment of women."<ref name="feminist.org"/> But this suggestion was not acted upon by the Eisenhower Administration.<ref name="feminist.org"/> In 1959, three landmark books on women were published: "A Century of Struggle" by [[Eleanor Flexner]], the first professional history of the 19th century women's movement, which contained an implicit call to arms; "A Century of Higher Education for American Women" by [[Mabel Newcomer]], which disclosed that the relative position of women in the academic world was in decline; and "Women and Work In America" by Robert Smuts, which drew attention to the fact that "the picture of women's occupations outside the home between 1890 and 1950 had changed in only a few essentials.<ref name="feminist.org"/>
In reaction to such findings, by 1961, President John F. Kennedy was under pressure to establish a President's Commission on the Status of Women.<ref name="feminist.org"/> Esther Peterson, Assistant Secretary of Labor and director of the Women's Bureau, and the highest ranking woman in the Kennedy Administration, wanted such a commission.<ref name="feminist.org"/> Along with equal pay legislation, it had long been on the agenda of labor movement women and it was in that movement that Peterson's working career had been concentrated.<ref name="feminist.org"/> Another wish of the women's movement, effective birth control, came true as in 1961 the first birth control pill, called Enovid, received FDA approval and went on the market.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/pill/timeline/timeline2.html |title=American Experience | The Pill | Timeline |publisher=Pbs.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Women's organizations, notably the American Association of University Women and Business and Professional Women, had been proposing a women's rights commission for many years; they found a champion in Eleanor Roosevelt, who backed the proposal when she met with Kennedy at the White House after his election.<ref name="feminist.org"/> The establishment of the Commission may also have been regarded by Kennedy as an expedient way to pay off his political debts to the women who had supported his campaign but were disappointed with his poor record of appointments of women to his administration.<ref name="feminist.org"/> There was also a desire to have Eleanor Roosevelt, one of the most respected women in the country, associated with the Kennedy Administration.<ref name="feminist.org"/> Roosevelt had only reluctantly supported JFK's presidential candidacy after her first choice, Adlai Stevenson, lost the nomination.<ref name="feminist.org"/> However, she agreed to be the Chairperson of the President's Commission on the Status of Women, which was held from 1961 until 1963.<ref name="feminist.org"/>
The Commission's Report, called "The American Woman" and issued in 1963, noted discrimination against women in the areas of education, home and community services, employment, social insurance and taxation, and legal, civil and political rights.<ref name="wifp.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.wifp.org/womensmediach2.html |title=Speaking Out for Equal Rights, Peace and Justice, 1963 Through 1970 |publisher=Wifp.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> The report also recommended continued network-building.<ref name="wifp.org"/> President Kennedy implemented two Commission recommendations that established an Interdepartmental Committee on the Status of Women and a Citizens' Advisory Council on the Status of Women, composed of twenty private citizens appointed by the President.<ref name="wifp.org"/> These two groups co-sponsored four national conferences of state commissions on the status of women.<ref name="wifp.org"/> Another important event of 1963 was the publication of Betty Friedan's influential book "The Feminine Mystique", which is often cited as the founding moment of second-wave feminism.<ref name="jwa.org">{{cite web|url=http://jwa.org/thisweek/feb/17/1963/betty-friedan |title=This Week in History - Publication of "The Feminine Mystique" by Betty Friedan | Jewish Women's Archive |publisher=Jwa.org |date=February 17, 1963 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> This book highlighted Friedan's view of a coercive and pervasive post-World War-II ideology of female domesticity that stifled middle-class women's opportunities to be anything but homemakers.<ref name="jwa.org"/> Friedan's book is credited with sparking second-wave feminism by directing women's attention to the broad social basis of their problems, stirring many to political and social activism.<ref name="jwa.org"/>
Also in 1963, President Kennedy signed the Equal Pay Act into law, which amended the Fair Labor Standards Act to prohibit pay discrimination because of sex.<ref name="feminism.eserver.org">{{cite web|url=http://feminism.eserver.org/workplace/wages/equal-pay.txt |title=Feminism and Women's Studies: A Working Woman's Guide to Her Rights |publisher=Feminism.eserver.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> It requires the employer to pay equal wages to men and women doing equal work on jobs requiring equal skill, effort, and responsibility, which are performed under similar working conditions.<ref name="feminism.eserver.org"/> Another accomplishment for feminism in 1963 was that feminist activist [[Gloria Steinem]] published her article ''I Was a Playboy Bunny'', a behind the scenes look at the sexist treatment of [[Playboy]] bunnies, which was one of her first major assignments in investigative journalism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gale.cengage.com/free_resources/whm/bio/steinem_g.htm |title=Gale - Free Resources - Women's History - Biographies - Gloria Steinem |publisher=Gale.cengage.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
There were several political firsts for women in the 1960s. On November 22, 1963, following the assassination of President Kennedy, federal judge [[Sarah T. Hughes]] administered the Presidential Oath of Office to Lyndon Johnson aboard Air Force One, the only time a woman has done so, as the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court normally has this honor. 1964 was the first year in which more women voted in a Presidential election than men; more women have voted than men in every Presidential election since.<ref>{{cite web|author=Max Temkin |url=http://www.votingwomen.org/votingpower.html |title=Education + Participation = Power |publisher=VotingWomen.org |date=August 3, 2010 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://www.canow.org/canoworg/2010/08/the-history-of-suffrage-and-women-voters.html]{{dead link|date=June 2011}}</ref>
One of the most important advances for women's rights in this decade was not begun by a feminist. On Saturday, February 8, 1964, while the Civil Rights Act was being debated on the House floor, Howard W. Smith of Virginia, Chairman of the Rules Committee and staunch opponent of all civil rights legislation, rose up and offered a one word amendment to Title VII, which prohibited employment discrimination.<ref name="uic.edu">{{cite web|url=http://www.uic.edu/orgs/cwluherstory/jofreeman/lawandpolicy/titlevii.htm |title=How "Sex" Got Into Title VII: Persistent Opportunism as a Maker of Public Policy |publisher=Uic.edu |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> He proposed to add "sex" to that one title of the bill in order "to prevent discrimination against another minority group, the women,".... (110 Cong. Rec., February 8, 1964, 2577).<ref name="uic.edu"/> This stimulated several hours of humorous debate, later called "ladies day in the House", before the amendment was passed by a teller vote of 168 to 133.<ref name="uic.edu"/> Howard W. Smith later confessed to his colleague, Congresswoman Martha Griffiths, "Martha, I’ll tell you the truth. I offered it as a joke."<ref>[http://www.topstoriespittsburgh.com/news/william-petrocelli-the-most-important-womens-rights-legislation-in-history-to-some-it-was-just-a-joke/]{{dead link|date=June 2011}}</ref> The [[Equal Employment Opportunity Commission]], in charge of the enforcement of Title VII, ignored sex discrimination complaints, and the prohibition against sex discrimination in employment went unenforced for the next few years.<ref name="google5">{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=DUqK99RZzdEC&pg=PA290 |title=The will of the people: how public ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> One EEOC director called the prohibition "a fluke...conceived out of wedlock," and even the liberal magazine "The New Republic" asked, "Why should a mischievous joke perpetrated on the floor of the House of Representatives be treated by a responsible administration body with this kind of seriousness?"<ref name="google5"/>
In 1966, at the third National Conference of State Commissions on the Status of Women, the conference organizers did not allow resolutions or actions of any kind meant to abolish discrimination against women, so some women who were attending decided to form an advocacy organization of their own.<ref name="google6">{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=yv_89YqMxZ4C&pg=RA1-PA204 |title=The Columbia documentary history of ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Cornering a large table at the conference luncheon, so that they could start organizing before they had to rush for planes, each of those women chipped in five dollars, Betty Friedan wrote the acronym NOW on a napkin, and the National Organization for Women was created.<ref name="google6"/> Its first meeting was held on June 28, 1966 in Betty Friedan's hotel room, with 28 women attending.<ref name="now.org">{{cite web|author=National Organization for Women |url=http://www.now.org/history/founders.html |title=Honoring Our Founders |publisher=Now.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> At its first conference in October 1966, Friedan was elected NOW's first president, and her fame as the author of the bestselling book ''The Feminine Mystique'' helped attract thousands of women to the organization.<ref name="now.org"/> Friedan drafted NOW's original Statement of Purpose, which began, "The purpose of NOW is to take action to bring women into full participation in the mainstream of American society now, exercising all the privileges and responsibilities thereof in truly equal partnership with men."<ref name="now.org"/> Furthermore, in 1966, Congresswoman [[Martha Griffiths]] admonished the EEOC on the floor of Congress for their failure to enforce the prohibition against sex discrimination in employment.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=C4IYnNCmmRUC&pg=PA253&lpg=PA253 |title=The hollow hope: can courts bring ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
Employment discrimination against women began to be taken more seriously in the late 1960s. In 1967, President [[Lyndon Johnson]] issued Executive Order 11375, which declared that federal employers must take affirmative action to ensure that employees receive equal treatment and opportunities regardless of gender, race, color, or religion.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=P0IXyvEGao8C&pg=PA190 |title=Women's rights: a global view - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1968 the EEOC, following two years of protests by NOW, banned all help wanted ads which specified which sex a job applicant should be, except those jobs for which being a certain sex was a bona fide occupational requirement (such as actress), opening many hitherto unattainable jobs to women.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=5kjkZjvnI-sC&pg=PA130 |title=Timelines of American women's history - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> The Supreme Court ruled the ban legal in Pittsburgh Press Co. v Pittsburgh Commission on Human Relations, 413 U.S. 376 (1973).<ref>http://www.justicelearning.org/justice_timeline/Issues.aspx?IssueID=13&TimelineID=54&TimelineEventID=1268] [http://books.google.com/books?id=Si6ZVqdOqIgC&pg=PA235]</ref>
There were several other feminist advances in the late 1960s, in both conservative and liberal circles. In 1968 conservative women separated from NOW and organized [[Women's Equity Action League]] (WEAL) to campaign for equal opportunities for women in education, economics, and employment, while avoiding issues such as abortion, sexuality, and the Equal Rights Amendment.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=R6UEj0ov2bQC&pg=PA111 |title=Encyclopedia of Title nine and sports - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Also in 1968, liberal activist [[Robin Morgan]] led a protest of the Miss America pageant in Atlantic City;<ref name="google7">{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=vRY27FkGJAUC&pg=PA368 |title=Culture wars: an encyclopedia of ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> at the protest a group of about one hundred women tossed items that they considered symbolic of women’s oppression into a Freedom Trash Can, including copies of Playboy, high-heeled shoes, corsets, and girdles.<ref name="newyorker.com">{{cite web|last=Levy |first=Ariel |url=http://www.newyorker.com/arts/critics/books/2009/11/16/091116crbo_books_levy |title=Feminism and Gail Collins’s "When Everything Changed" |publisher=The New Yorker |date=January 7, 2009 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> They also crowned a sheep as Miss America.<ref name="google7"/> [[Lindsy Van Gelder]], a reporter for the Post, wrote a piece about the protest in which she compared the trash-can procession to the burning of draft cards at antiwar marches.<ref name="newyorker.com"/> However, the rumor that women burned their bras at the protest is not true.<ref name="newyorker.com"/>
Litigation for women's rights now began to have a serious impact on American life. In 1969 California adopted the nation’s first [[no-fault divorce]] law, which was intended to promote equality between men and women.<ref name="justicelearning.org">[http://www.justicelearning.org/justice_timeline/Issues.aspx?IssueID=13&TimelineID=54&TimelineEventID=1268]</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=nnXY4iV1lRcC&pg=PA153 |title=The Consequences of divorce ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> By 2010, all 50 states had legalized no-fault divorce, with New York being the last state to do so.<ref>{{cite web|author=Beverly Willett |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2010-08-28/no-fault-divorce-my-fight-to-save-my-marriage/ |title=No-Fault Divorce: My Fight to Save My Marriage |publisher=The Daily Beast |date=August 28, 2010 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1969 the case Weeks v Southern Bell was decided in favor of [[Lorena Weeks]], who had applied for a better job as a switchperson, but had her application rejected because, her union boss said, "the man is the breadwinner in the family, and women just do not need this type of job."<ref name="allbusiness.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.allbusiness.com/legal/labor-employment-law-discrimination-gender-sex/14174508-1.html |title=Business solutions from |publisher=AllBusiness.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Weeks filed a complaint with the EEOC, but the phone company cited a Georgia law that prohibited women from lifting anything heavier than 30 pounds, although the 34-pound manual typewriter Weeks used as a clerk had to be lifted by hand onto her desk every morning and stored away every night.<ref name="allbusiness.com"/> After the case was decided, she received $31,000 in back pay and got the job.<ref name="allbusiness.com"/> In the 1971 Supreme Court case [[Reed v Reed]], the Supreme Court ruled that it is illegal for any state to prefer all men over all women as administrators of assets.<ref name="supremecourthistory.org">[http://www.supremecourthistory.org/learning/supremecourthistory_learning_womens2.htm]{{dead link|date=June 2011}}</ref> This was the first time ever that the Court had struck down a state law on the ground that it discriminated against women in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th amendment.<ref name="supremecourthistory.org"/>
In addition to litigation, feminist activists also began to form their own institutions to propagate their ideals. In 1971 Rep. [[Bella Abzug]], [[Betty Friedan]], and [[Gloria Steinem]] founded the [[National Women's Political Caucus]] to advocate for more women and feminists in elective office.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=bzLCEhRx39wC&pg=PA67 |title=Women and political participation: a ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Also in 1971, [[Gloria Steinem]] and others began publishing [[Ms. Magazine]], the first national feminist magazine<ref name="google.com">http://www.google.com/search?tbs=bks%3A1&tbo=1&q=%22 ms+magazine+%22+%22first+national+feminist+magazine%22</ref> The first three hundred thousand copies of Ms. sold out in eight days; the magazine name comes from the fact that the title Ms. was originally popularized by feminists in the 1970s to replace Miss and Mrs. and provide a parallel term to Mr., in that both Ms. and Mr. designate gender without indicating marital status.<ref name="google.com"/><ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=EZ-yXBMtFysC&pg=PA167 |title=The feminist critique of language: a ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=March 25, 1998 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1972, former NOW members [[Pat Goltz]] and [[Cathy Callaghan]] founded [[Feminists for Life]], with the goal of eliminating the root causes that they felt drove women to abortion, contending that abortion violated core feminist principles of justice, non-discrimination and [[nonviolence]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.feministsforlife.org/who/joinus.htm|title=Feminists for Life}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.feministsforlife.org/news/human-life-review.htm|title=''Human Life Review''}}</ref>
One of the most important feminist successes of the early 1970s was when Nixon signed into law the [[Equal Employment Opportunity Act|Equal Employment Opportunity Act of 1972]] and [[Title IX]] of the Education Amendments of 1972.<ref name="definitions.uslegal.com">{{cite web|url=http://definitions.uslegal.com/e/equal-employment-opportunity-act/ |title=Equal Employment Opportunity Act Law & Legal Definition |publisher=Definitions.uslegal.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> The [[Equal Employment Opportunity Act|Equal Employment Opportunity Act of 1972]] gives the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) authority to sue in federal courts when it finds reasonable cause to believe that there has been employment discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin.<ref name="definitions.uslegal.com"/> In the case of public employment, the EEOC refers the matter to the United States Attorney General to bring the lawsuit.<ref name="definitions.uslegal.com"/> [[Title IX]] of the Education Amendments of 1972 requires gender equity in every educational program that receives federal funding including but not limited to sports.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.titleix.info/History/History-Overview.aspx |title=History Overview |publisher=TitleIX.info |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
However, the feminist movement did have some notable setbacks around this time. In 1972 President Nixon vetoed the [[Comprehensive Child Development Bill of 1972]], which many feminists advocated and which would have established both early-education programs and after-school care across the country, with tuition on a sliding scale based on a family’s income bracket, and the program available to everyone but participation required of no one.<ref name="newyorker.com"/> The [[Equal Rights Amendment]] passed the Senate and then the House of Representatives in 1972, and on March 22, 1972, it was sent to the states for ratification.<ref name="equalrightsamendment.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.equalrightsamendment.org/era.htm |title=History |publisher=Equalrightsamendment.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> However, it was not ratified before the deadline for ratification passed, and therefore never became law.<ref name="equalrightsamendment.org"/> The most influential ERA opponent was Phyllis Schlafly, right-wing leader of the Eagle Forum/STOP ERA, who claimed that the ERA would deny a woman’s right to be supported by her husband, privacy rights would be overturned, women would be sent into combat, and abortion rights and same-sex marriages would be upheld.<ref name="equalrightsamendment.org"/> Furthermore, some states'-rights advocates thought the ERA was a federal power grab, and business interests such as the insurance industry opposed a measure they believed would cost them money.<ref name="equalrightsamendment.org"/> Opposition to the ERA was also organized by fundamentalist religious groups.<ref name="equalrightsamendment.org"/> Pro-ERA advocacy was led by the National Organization for Women (NOW) and ERAmerica, a coalition of nearly 80 other organizations.<ref name="equalrightsamendment.org"/>
One of the most controversial developments in American women's lives has been the legalization of abortion. In 1973 in the Supreme Court case [[Roe v Wade]], the Supreme Court ruled that it is an illegal violation of privacy to outlaw or regulate any aspect of abortion performed during the first trimester of pregnancy, and that government can only enact abortion regulations reasonably related to maternal health in the second and third trimesters, and can enact abortion laws protecting the life of the fetus only in the third trimester.<ref name="autogenerated4">{{cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/wnet/supremecourt/rights/landmark_roe.html |title=The Supreme Court . Expanding Civil Rights . Landmark Cases . Roe v. Wade (1973) |publisher=PBS |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Furthermore, even in the third trimester, an exception has to be made to protect the life of the mother.<ref name="autogenerated4"/> This ruling has been extremely controversial from the moment it was made.<ref name="autogenerated4"/> [[Linda Coffee]] and [[Sarah Weddington]] had brought the lawsuit that led to Roe v Wade on behalf of a pregnant woman, Dallas area resident [[Norma McCorvey|Norma L. McCorvey]] ("Jane Roe"), claiming a Texas law criminalizing most abortions violated Roe's constitutional rights.<ref name="autogenerated4"/> The Texas law banned all abortions except those necessary to save the life of the mother, and Roe claimed that while her life was not endangered, she could not afford to travel out of state and had a right to terminate her pregnancy in a safe medical environment.<ref name="autogenerated4"/>
One of the most famous feminist media events, aside from the 1968 Miss America protest, was the tennis match known as the "Battle of the Sexes." In this match, on September 20, 1973, in Houston, Texas, women's tennis champion [[Billie Jean King]] defeated Bobby Riggs 6-4, 6-3, 6-3, before a worldwide television audience estimated at almost 50 million.<ref name="espn.go.com">{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/sportscentury/features/00016060.html |title=ESPN.com: Billie Jean won for all women |publisher=Espn.go.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> 55-year-old former tennis champion [[Bobby Riggs]] had defeated Australian tennis player [[Margaret Court]] earlier that year, and he was an outspoken opponent of feminism, saying for example, "If a woman wants to get in the headlines, she should have quintuplets,"<ref>{{cite news| url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1007362/index.htm | work=CNN | title=Video | date=November 6, 1995}}</ref> " and calling himself a "male chauvinist pig".<ref name="espn.go.com"/>
There were a few important legal gains for women in the mid-1970s. The [[Women's Educational Equity Act]], enacted in 1974, provides federal funds for projects designed to promote gender equity in the curriculum, in counseling and guidance, in physical education, and in the development of classroom materials.<ref name="college.cengage.com">http://www.college.cengage.com/history/readerscomp/women/html/wh_040100_womenseducat.htm</ref> The Act also supports activities for reentering women students, expanding vocational and career education for women, and funding women's resource center initiatives.<ref name="college.cengage.com"/> The [[Equal Credit Opportunity Act]], enacted in 1974, illegalizes credit discrimination on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, marital status, age, or because someone receives public assistance.<ref name="ftc.gov">{{cite web|url=http://www.ftc.gov/bcp/edu/pubs/consumer/credit/cre15.shtm |title=Equal Credit Opportunity: Understanding Your Rights Under the Law |publisher=Ftc.gov |date=April 7, 2010 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Due to this Act, creditors may ask you for most of this information in certain situations, but they may not use it when deciding whether to give you credit or when setting the terms of your credit.<ref name="ftc.gov"/> In the 1975 Supreme Court case [[Taylor v Louisiana]], the Supreme Court ruled that excluding women from the jury pool is illegal because it violates a person's right to a fair trial by a representative segment of the community.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mass.gov/courts/sjc/jury-system-e.html |title=The Jury System - Inclusion of Minorities and Women |publisher=Mass.gov |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1978, the [[Pregnancy Discrimination Act]] was passed, making employment discrimination on the basis of pregnancy, childbirth, or related medical conditions illegal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eeoc.gov/facts/fs-preg.html |title=Facts About Pregnancy Discrimination |publisher=Eeoc.gov |date=September 8, 2008 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
Another important event around this time was the Vietnam War. Approximately 7,000 American military women served in Vietnam during the Vietnam War (1965–1975), the majority of them as nurses.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/><ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=PD8WAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA20 |title=Women veterans' benefits and ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=August 21, 1991 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> An Army nurse, Sharon Ann Lane, was the only U.S. military woman to die from enemy fire in Vietnam.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usar.army.mil/arweb/newsandmedia/storiesfromthefront/Pages/womens_history_lane.aspx |title=1st Lt. Sharon A. Lane |publisher=Usar.army.mil |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> An Air Force flight nurse, Capt Mary Therese Klinker, died when the C-5A Galaxy transport evacuating Vietnamese orphans which she was aboard crashed on takeoff.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=8774295 |title=Capt Mary Therese Klinker (1947 - 1975) - Find A Grave Memorial |publisher=Findagrave.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Six other American military women also died in the line of duty.<ref name="womensmemorial.org"/> An important gain for military women occurred when in 1976, the five federal United States Service academies (West Point, Coast Guard Academy, Naval Academy, Air Force Academy, Merchant Marines Academy) were required to admit women as a result of Public Law 94-106 signed by President Gerald Ford on Oct. 7, 1975.<ref name="womensmemorial1">{{cite web|url=http://www.womensmemorial.org/H&C/History/milacad.html |title=Women In Military Service For America Memorial |publisher=Womensmemorial.org |date=October 7, 1975 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> The law passed the House by a vote of 303 to 96 and the Senate by voice vote after divisive argument within Congress, resistance from the Department of Defense and legal action initiated by women to challenge their exclusion.<ref name="womensmemorial1"/> More than 300 women enrolled in the academies in 1976.<ref name="womensmemorial1"/>
During the 1970s, feminists also worked to bring greater attention and help to women suffering from domestic violence and rape.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=Z8tSQRg7FgIC&pg=PA40 |title=Feminists negotiate the state: the ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> While it is not true that the expression "rule of thumb" comes from men beating women with sticks as big as their thumbs, as has been rumored,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.debunker.com/texts/ruleofthumb.html |title=The "Rule of Thumb for Wife-Beating" Hoax |publisher=Debunker.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> it is true that little help was available to battered women before the 1970s, when some of the first battered women's shelters were created and states began adopting domestic violence laws providing for civil orders of protection and better police protection (the first "modern" women's shelter in the world was Haven House, which opened in 1964 in [[California]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jfsla.org/havenhouse/domestic_violence/shelter/prevention_education/C61#contentPrimary |title=jfsla.org |publisher=Jewish Family Service of Los Angeles |date=2012-05-29 |accessdate=2012-06-05}}{{Failed verification|date=June 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=LJX3Ql7bu2YC&pg=PA1023 |title=Encyclopedia of crime and punishment - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=March 18, 2002 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> It is not true that either Catherine MacKinnon or Andrea Dworkin (both feminist activists) said "all sex is rape", or "all men are rapists," or "all sex is sexual harassment", as has been rumored;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snopes.com/quotes/mackinnon.asp |title=Catherine MacKinnon 'All Sex is Rape' Quote |publisher=snopes.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> however, during the 1970s feminist activists worked to change laws stating that there had to be a witness other than the woman herself to charge a man with rape, and that a woman's sexual history could be brought up at trial, while the alleged rapist's could not.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=EDd2aNCoGlYC&pg=PA107 |title=Public Women, Public Words: A ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=March 28, 2005 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Also, due to feminist activism the first law against marital rape (raping one's spouse) was enacted by South Dakota in 1975.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ZobatN9UcpEC&pg=PA326 |title=Sex for Dummies - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=October 20, 2006 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> By 1993, marital rape had become a crime in all 50 states in America.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ZHAfpoCO5yMC&pg=PA83 |title=Fundamentals of Criminal Justice: A ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
The 1980s brought more firsts for American women. 1980 was the first year that a higher percentage of women than men voted in a Presidential election, and a higher percentage of women than men have voted in every Presidential election since.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apsanet.org/content_5270.cfm |title=Women Voters and the Gender Gap | APSA |publisher=Apsanet.org |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1981 [[Sandra Day O'Connor]] was confirmed unanimously by the Senate and became the first female Supreme Court Justice.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oyez.org/justices/sandra_day_oconnor |title=Sandra Day O'Connor | The Oyez Project at IIT Chicago-Kent College of Law |publisher=Oyez.org |date=March 26, 1930 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1983 [[Sally Ride]] became the first female American astronaut.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jsc.nasa.gov/Bios/htmlbios/ride-sk.html |title=Astronaut Bio: Sally K. Ride |publisher=Jsc.nasa.gov |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1984, [[Geraldine Ferraro]] became the first woman nominated for Vice President by a major party (the Democratic Party), although she was not elected.<ref>[http://www.greatwomen.org/women.php?action=viewone&id=61]</ref> Also, in 1984 [[Katherine Sullivan]] became the first American woman to walk in space.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/facts/Space/index.html |title=NASA - Facts |publisher=Nasa.gov |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1987 [[Wilma Mankiller]] became the first woman to be elected chief of a major Native American tribe (Cherokee).<ref name="nytimes1">{{cite news| url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/07/us/07mankiller.html | work=The New York Times | title=Wilma Mankiller, Cherokee Chief and First Woman to Lead Major Tribe, Is Dead at 64 | date=April 6, 2010}}</ref> In 1991 she was re-elected with 83% of the vote; during her tenure the Cherokee nation’s membership more than doubled, to 170,000 from about 68,000.<ref name="nytimes1"/> In 1987, Congress declared March as the first National [[Women's History Month]]. A special Presidential Proclamation is issued every year since which honors the achievements of American women.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nwhp.org/whm/history.php |title=National Women's History Project |publisher=Nwhp.org |date=March 8, 1980 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
Younger women now began to be more involved in feminism. In the early 1990s, [[third wave feminism]] began as a response to the second wave's perceived inadequacies and shortcomings.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=CdNCI-m8Lc0C&pg=PA278 |title=Approaches to Political Thought - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Third wave feminism, which continues today, is most often associated with a younger generation of feminist activism, an interest in popular culture and sexual agency, and an acceptance of pluralism and contradiction.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=gqCoOSsnOeEC&pg=PA13 |title=Nightwood Theatre: a woman's work is ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date=January 30, 2010 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1991 in Olympia, Washington, [[Riot grrrl]] began in reaction to the domination of the punk rock scene of America's Pacific Northwest by all-male bands, and as an attempt to establish a female-friendly presence within this scene.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=uX2DajVRUOIC&pg=PA238 |title=Women in German Yearbook, Volume 21 ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Riot grrrl consisted of feminist punk bands such as Bikini Kill and Bratmobile, and their zines, meetings and songs.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=1aIej6WjeqEC&pg=PA19 |title=Everything you need to know about ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
The concerns of military women again came to the fore as the Persian Gulf War (1990–1991) utilized an unprecedented proportion of women from the active forces (7%) as well as the Reserve and National Guard (17%).<ref name="userpages.aug.com">{{cite web|url=http://userpages.aug.com/captbarb/femvetsds.html |title=American Women in Uniform, Desert Storm |publisher=Userpages.aug.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Over 40,000 US military women served in combat support positions throughout the war.<ref name="userpages.aug.com"/> Sixteen women died during the war and two were held prisoner.<ref name="userpages.aug.com"/> In 1991 the [[Tailhook]] Scandal occurred at the annual Tailhook Association convention held in Las Vegas, with more than 26 women (14 of them officers) being assaulted by scores of drunken naval and marine officers.<ref name="google1991">{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=8kETsH4flCMC&pg=PA220 |title=Encyclopedia of women in American ... - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Accusations that the Navy mishandled the subsequent investigation were deeply damaging to the Navy's reputation.<ref name="google1991"/>
Another famous sexual harassment case occurred when in 1991 [[Anita Hill]], a law professor at the University of Oklahoma, came forward with accusations that [[Clarence Thomas]] (who had just been nominated for the Supreme Court) had sexually harassed her.<ref name="chnm.gmu.edu">{{cite web|url=http://chnm.gmu.edu/courses/122/hill/hilloutline2.htm |title=An Outline of the Anita Hill and Clarence Thomas Controversy |publisher=Chnm.gmu.edu |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> Hill had worked for Thomas years earlier when he was head of the [[Equal Employment Opportunity Commission]], and she charged that Thomas harassed her with inappropriate discussion of sexual acts and pornographic films after she rebuffed his invitations to date him.<ref name="chnm.gmu.edu"/> When Thomas testified against Hill's claims before the Senate Judiciary Committee, he called the hearings, "a high-tech lynching for uppity blacks," although Hill herself was black.<ref name="chnm.gmu.edu"/> In the end, the Senate voted 52-48 to confirm Clarence Thomas as an associate justice of the Supreme Court.<ref name="chnm.gmu.edu"/>
The 1990s brought more firsts for women in politics and the military. 1992 was known as the "[[Year of the Woman]]" because more women than ever before were elected to political office that year (women gained 19 House and 3 Senate seats for a total of 47 seats in the House and seven seats in the Senate) including [[Carol Moseley Braun]], the first black female senator.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.senate.gov/pagelayout/history/h_multi_sections_and_teasers/Photo_Exhibit_African_American_Senators.htm |title=U.S. Senate: Art & History Home > Photo Exhibit |publisher=Senate.gov |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> In 1993 [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg]] was confirmed by Congress as a Supreme Court Justice, becoming the second woman on the court.
