In 1994 [[Shannon Faulkner]] applied to the [[The Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina]] and was accepted for admission.<ref name="science.howstuffworks.com">{{cite web|last=Freudenrich |first=Craig |url=http://science.howstuffworks.com/citadel5.htm |title=HowStuffWorks "Women and The Citadel" |publisher=Science.howstuffworks.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> She had left her gender information off the application.<ref name="science.howstuffworks.com"/> When it was discovered that she was a woman, The Citadel revoked her offer, so Faulkner filed suit against The Citadel to gain admission.<ref name="science.howstuffworks.com"/> The court rejected The Citadel's arguments, clearing her way to attend the school under court order.<ref name="science.howstuffworks.com"/> Faulkner became the first female cadet in 1995, but resigned a few days into her first week.<ref name="science.howstuffworks.com"/> A similar case occurred about this time that forced the [[Virginia Military Institute]] to open its doors to women.<ref name="science.howstuffworks.com"/> On June 28, 1996, two days after the U.S. Supreme Court's decision in [[United States v Virginia]], the Citadel's governing board voted unanimously to remove a person's gender as a requirement for admission.<ref name="science.howstuffworks.com"/> In 1999 [[Nancy Mace]] became the first woman to graduate from the Citadel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.citadel.edu/pao/women/coeducation_timeline.html |title=Citadel news release |publisher=Citadel.edu |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> The first women graduated from the Virginia Military Institute in 2001 (Melissa Graham of Burleson, Texas, and Chih-Yuan Ho of Taipei, Taiwan).<ref>http://www.roanoke.com/roatimes/vmi/v78.html</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/may/20/news/mn-397 | work=Los Angeles Times | title=VMI's First Female Cadets Graduate | date=May 20, 2001}}</ref>
Two important cases concerning women's rights were litigated in the late 1990s. The [[Matter of Kasinga]] was a legal case decided in June 1996 involving Fauziya Kassindja (surname also spelled as Kasinga), a [[Togo]]lese teenager seeking [[asylum in the United States]] in order to escape a tribal practice of [[female genital mutilation]].<ref>Dugger, Celia W. "[http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C05E1DB1439F935A25755C0A960958260 Asylum from Mutilation]". ''[[New York Times]]''. 16 June 2006. Retrieved 8 August 2008.</ref> The [[Board of Immigration Appeals]] granted her asylum in June 1996 after an earlier judge denied her claims. The case set a precedent in United States [[immigration law]] as applicants could now seek asylum in the United States from gender-based persecution, whereas previously religious or political grounds were often used to grant asylum. In 1999 [[Lilly Ledbetter]], a supervisor at a Goodyear tire plant in Alabama, sued Goodyear because she was being paid at least 15% less than the men who held the same job.<ref name="articles.latimes.com">{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/may/30/nation/na-scotus30 | work=The Los Angeles Times | title=Only fresh bias counts, court rules | first=David G. | last=Savage | date=May 30, 2007}}</ref> A jury sided with her and awarded her back pay of $224,000 and nearly $3.3 million in punitive damages, but the company appealed, arguing she filed her claim too late, and it won a reversal from a U.S. appeals court in Atlanta.<ref name="articles.latimes.com"/> In 2007 the Supreme Court agreed with the company and ruled that her suit should have been thrown out at the start because it relied on evidence of discrimination in the 1980s, not on unfair pay decisions in 1998 or 1999; the Supreme Court declared that employees wishing to file discrimination charges must do so no more than 180 days after they have received their first discriminatory paycheck, although Lilly Ledbetter did not know she had been discriminated against in pay until much more than 180 days had passed.<ref name="articles.latimes.com"/> However, in 2009 President Barack Obama signed the [[Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act]] into law (the first bill signed into law during his presidency), which changed the law so that now workers can sue up to 180 days after receiving any discriminatory paycheck, not just the first discriminatory paycheck.<ref name="articles.latimes.com"/>
==2000 – present== [[File:Gen Ann Dunwoody.jpg|thumb|left|125px|Ann Dunwoody, the first female four-star general in the United States military (shown while two-star general).]]
From 2003 until 2011, American women soldiers served in the [[Iraq War]].<ref>[http://news.yahoo.com/nearly-nine-years-u-withdraws-iraq-043831767.html Last U.S. troops leave Iraq, ending war - Yahoo! News]{{dead link|date=April 2012}}</ref> This time included several firsts for women in the military. In 2008, [[Ann Dunwoody]] became the first female four-star general in the United States military.<ref>{{cite web|last=Asfar |first=Roy |url=https://www.veteransadvantage.com/cms/content/ann-dunwoody |title=Ann Dunwoody:First Female 4-Star General|Top Vets |publisher=Veterans Advantage |date=November 24, 2008 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/11/14/national/main4602923.shtml | work=CBS News | title=U.S. Names First Female 4-Star General | date=November 14, 2008}}</ref> In 2011, [[Sandra Stosz]] assumed command of the U.S. Coast Guard Academy, becoming the first woman superintendent of that institution, and the first woman to command any U.S. service academy.<ref name="uscg.mil"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Bacewicz |first=Tony |url=http://newlondon.patch.com/articles/video-coast-guard-academy-welcomes-first-woman-superintendent#video-6396214 |title=newlondon.patch.com |publisher=newlondon.patch.com |date=3 June 2011 }}</ref> Also in 2011, [[Patricia Horoho]] became the first female U.S. Army surgeon general.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.armytimes.com/news/2011/12/army-first-female-surgeon-general-sworn-in-121711w/ |title=Army’s first female surgeon general sworn in – Army News | News from Afghanistan & Iraq |publisher=Army Times }}</ref>
In 2004, [[Del Martin and Phyllis Lyon]] became the first same-sex couple to be legally married in the United States,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2004/02/12/GAYMARRIAGE.TMP | work=The San Francisco Chronicle | deadurl=yes}} {{Dead link|date=August 2012|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> since San Francisco mayor Gavin Newsom allowed city hall to grant marriage licenses to same-sex couples.<ref>{{cite web|author=by Jonathan DarmanJanuary 17, 2009 |url=http://www.newsweek.com/2009/01/16/hoping-that-left-is-right.html |title=SF Mayor Gavin Newsom Risks Career on Gay Marriage |publisher=Newsweek |date=January 17, 2009 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> However, all same-sex marriages done in 2004 in California were annulled.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/US/12/19/california.proposition/index.html | work=CNN | title=Prop 8 proponents seek to nullify same-sex marriages | date=December 19, 2008}}</ref> But after the California Supreme Court decision in 2008 that granted same-sex couples in California the right to marry, Del Martin and Phyllis Lyon remarried, and were again the first same-sex couple in the state to marry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gaypeopleschronicle.com/stories08/june/0613082.htm |title=First couple in California's 2004 marriages will say vows again on Monday |publisher=Gaypeopleschronicle.com |date=June 13, 2008 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/16/us/16cnd-weddings.html?hp | work=The New York Times | title=Gay Marriages Begin in California | first=Jesse | last=McKinley | date=June 16, 2008}}</ref> Later in 2008 Prop 8 illegalized same-sex marriage in California,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tuftsdaily.com/editorial-maine-was-asking-the-wrong-people-1.2058087#3 |title=Editorial | Maine was asking the wrong people - Tufts Daily - Tufts University |publisher=Tufts Daily |date=November 9, 2009 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> but the marriages that occurred between the California Supreme Court decision legalizing same-sex marriage and the approval of Prop 8 illegalizing it are still considered valid, including the marriage of Del Martin and Phyllis Lyon.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Justice/2009/0527/p02s01-usju.html |title=California's top court upholds Prop. 8 ban on same-sex marriage |publisher=CSMonitor.com |date=May 27, 2009 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
American women achieved many political firsts in the 2000s. In 2007, [[Nancy Pelosi]] became the first female Speaker of the House of Representatives;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whorunsgov.com/Profiles/Nancy_Pelosi |title=Nancy Pelosi, House Minority Leader, Nancy Pelosi California, Congresswoman Nancy Pelosi - WhoRunsGov.com/The Washington Post |publisher=Whorunsgov.com |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> she held the position for just under four years. In 2008 Democratic presidential candidate [[Hillary Clinton]] became the first woman to win a presidential primary, winning the New Hampshire Democratic primary although polls had predicted she would lose.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/22551718/ |title=N.H. stunner: Clinton defeats Obama - politics - Decision '08 - msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |date=January 9, 2008 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://progressive.stanford.edu/cgi-bin/article.php?article_id=205 |title=The Stanford Progressive |publisher=Progressive.stanford.edu |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> She eventually lost the Democratic nomination for President to Barack Obama, who went on to become President;<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/jun/04/barackobama.hillaryclinton | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=US elections: Barack Obama wins Democratic nomination for president | first1=Ewen | last1=MacAskill | first2=Suzanne | last2=Goldenberg | date=June 4, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/27531033/ |title=Obama elected 44th president - politics - Decision '08 - msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |date=November 5, 2008 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref> however, Hillary Clinton did receive 18 million votes.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/washington/2008/08/hillary-clint-4.html | work=The Los Angeles Times | title=Top of the Ticket | date=August 26, 2008}}</ref> In 2008, Alaska governor [[Sarah Palin]] became the first woman nominated for Vice President by the Republican Party, although she was not elected.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/08/29/AR2008082901112.html | work=The Washington Post | title=McCain Picks Alaska Governor; Palin First Woman on GOP Ticket | first1=Robert | last1=Barnes | first2=Michael D. | last2=Shear | date=August 30, 2008}}</ref> In 2009 and 2010, respectively, [[Sonia Sotomayor]] and [[Elena Kagan]] were confirmed as Supreme Court Associate Justices, making them the third and fourth female justices, but because Justice O'Connor had previously retired, this made the first time three women have served together on the Supreme Court. Sen. [[Barbara Mikulski]] of Maryland was re-elected to a fifth term in 2010; when the 112th Congress was sworn in, she became the longest serving female senator ever, passing Sen. [[Margaret Chase Smith]]. During this term, she surpassed [[Edith Nourse Rogers]] as the woman to serve the longest in the U.S. Congress.<ref>{{cite news|last=O'Keefe |first=Ed |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/2chambers/post/barbara-mikulski-honored-as-longest-serving-woman-in-congress/2012/03/21/gIQA6d5JSS_blog.html |title=Barbara Mikulski honored as longest-serving woman in Congress - 2chambers |publisher=The Washington Post |date=March 21, 2012 |accessdate=April 3, 2012}}</ref>
In 2009, due to the [[Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act]] being signed into law, the definition of federal hate crime was expanded to include those violent crimes in which the victim is selected due to their actual or perceived gender and/or gender identity; previously federal hate crimes were defined as only those violent crimes where the victim is selected due to their race, color, religion, or national origin.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/09/us/politics/09hate.html | work=The New York Times | title=House Votes to Expand Hate Crimes Definition | first=Carl | last=Hulse | date=October 9, 2009}}</ref> Furthermore, the Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act requires the Federal Bureau of Investigation to track statistics on hate crimes based on gender and gender identity (statistics for the other groups were already tracked).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hrc.org/laws_and_elections/5660.htm |title=Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act |publisher=HRC |date= |accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref>
